       Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a         </span>\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">John R Lucey</a><span class='delimiter'></span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    John R Lucey\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\"><div class=\"institution\">Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, Departments of id=\"contrib-orcid-0000-0002-9748-961X\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9748-961X\">\r\n            <img class=\"orchid-icon\" alt=\"OrcId icon\" aria-hidden=\"true\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443538 id=\"201443538\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Low-redshift strong-lensing galaxies can provide robust measurements of the stellar mass-to-light ratios in early-type galaxies (ETGs), and hence constrain variations in the stellar initial mass function (IMF). At present, only a few such systems are known. Here, we report the first results from a blind search for gravitationally lensed emission-line sources behind 52 massive <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.07 ETGs with Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) integral field spectroscopy. For 16 galaxies, new observations were acquired, whilst the other 36 were analysed from archival data. This project has previously yielded one confirmed galaxy-scale strong lens (J0403\u22120239) that we report in an earlier paper. J0403\u22120239 has since received follow-up observations, presented here, which indicate support for our earlier IMF results. Three cluster-scale, and hence dark-matter-dominated, lensing systems were also discovered (central galaxies of A4059, A2052, and AS555). For nine further galaxies, we detect a singly imaged but closely projected source within 6\u2009arcsec (including one candidate with sources at three different redshifts); such cases can be exploited to derive upper limits on the IMF mass-excess factor, \u03b1. Combining the new lens and new upper limits, with the previously discovered systems, we infer an average \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 (marginalized over the intrinsic scatter), which is inconsistent with a Salpeter-like IMF (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.55) at the 6\u03c3 level. We test the detection threshold in these short-exposure MUSE observations with the injection and recovery of simulated sources, and predict that one in 25 observations is expected to yield a new strong-lens system. Our observational results are consistent with this expected yield.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD&quot;\">galaxies: elliptical and lenticular, cD</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: stellar content&quot;\">galaxies: stellar content</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443540 id=\"201443540\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Zwicky (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1937</a>) first described how a nearby galaxy could act as a gravitational lens to a more distant source, and the resulting lensed images could be of sufficient size and surface brightness to be observable. The first discovered lensed images were a pair of quasars at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.41 separated by 6\u2009arcsec with near-identical spectra (Walsh, Carswell\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>). Recent lensing studies, with better characterized lens light profiles, provide key constraints on a wide range of astrophysical quantities, such as H<sub>0</sub>, general relativity and the nature of dark matter (DM; e.g. Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ritondale et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>)</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Strong lensing measures the total mass, including DM as well as stars, projected within the Einstein radius, (<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>). In cases where the relative contributions of the two components can be distinguished, the stellar mass-to-light ratio (\u03a5) can be determined. This is particularly important when investigating the stellar initial mass function (IMF), which is a key component of galaxy evolution, and for interpreting observed properties, e.g. estimating stellar masses. The IMF is probed via the mass-excess parameter (\u03b1): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\alpha = \\dfrac{\\Upsilon }{\\Upsilon _{\\rm Ref}} ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>which compares a measured \u03a5 to a reference mass-to-light ratio (\u03a5<sub>ref</sub>) for a modelled stellar populations with a fixed IMF. Disentangling the dark and stellar matter, in general, requires additional information that can in principle be determined from stellar dynamics (i.e. SLACS; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). However, this technique requires further modelling assumptions and appears to require the addition of \u03a5 gradients to match similar measurements from weak-lensing constraints (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Within a galaxy, the stars are more centrally concentrated than the DM halo, e.g. an NFW halo (Navarro, Frenk\u00a0&amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). Lenses in which the <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> occurs at a fraction of the effective radius (<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>) directly probe the stellar content of a galaxy. For low-redshift lenses (<em>z</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a00.1), the required critical density for forming multiple images is higher (compared to the same lens, but more distant from the observer) and is therefore exceeded only at small physical radius where the stars contribute up to 80\u00a0per\u2009cent of the mass.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recent efforts to detect low-redshift strong-lensing early-type galaxies (ETGs) have been driven largely by the seeming discrepancy between the measured \u03b1 parameters of the SLACS lenses (\u2329<em>z</em>\u232a\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.2), compared to those from the SINFONI nearby elliptical lens locator survey (SNELLS; Smith, Lucey\u00a0&amp; Conroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, \u2329<em>z</em>\u232a\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.03). These two samples measure significantly different IMFs within massive (high-velocity dispersion) ETGs, i.e. at the 3\u03c3 level. Additionally, these SNELLS lenses are valuable as they provide a \u2018golden sample\u2019 for which all three of the main IMF tracing techniques, strong-lensing, stellar dynamics, and spectral synthesis, can be applied, and therefore contrasted (Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). However, observable strong-gravitational lensing by nearby massive ETGs is inherently rare.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Techniques used to discover the current sample of galaxy-scale lenses fall broadly into two categories: those searching spatially within imaging and those using single-fibre spectroscopy to detect background emission-line objects. Within imaging the preferred methods focus on identifying either elongated arcs (i.e. strong lensing challenge; Metcalf et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) or multiple sources with similar colour properties distinct from the foreground galaxies (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lucey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Delchambre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lemon, Auger\u00a0&amp; McMahon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The second category yields lenses from spectral features distinct from the foreground galaxy in redshift space, within large spectroscopic surveys [e.g. sloan digital sky survey (SDSS)]. In most systems, the background source is detected in emission (e.g. sloan lens ACS survey (SLACS), boss emission-line lens survey (BELLS); Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Brownstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). However, it is also possible to detect background absorption line systems (i.e. Early-Early Lenses; Oldham et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The foreground lens galaxy is fitted with a model spectrum, and then the residual is searched for higher redshift residual features. Due to the small angular size of a fibre (e.g. 3\u2009arcsec, SDSS), if a background source is detected, it is likely to lie within the multiply imaged region of the source plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For lens systems identified through either of the classical techniques, the discovery data are generally not sufficient for a full analysis. Imaging only reveals the number, and fluxes of potential images, but does not provide the redshifts which are required to confirm a single source of origin. Conversely spectroscopy only confirms the redshift of a background object, but not the configuration. Therefore neither of these are observationally efficient. Furthermore the discovered lens systems are biased by the detection method. To detect within imaging alone, the lensed sources must be resolved against the foreground lens light, and hence frequently lie at high angular separation (compared to the lens <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>). Spectroscopic searches however, are limited by the fibre size. To detect an emission line enough of the lensed image flux must be contained within a fibre, which may not be the case for highly asymmetric systems. Therefore both of these techniques may fail to detect valid strong-lensing systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The advent of large field-of-view (FoV) integral field units (IFU) with sufficient angular and spectral resolution, offers a third approach for lens discovery. IFU observations make use of spectral pixels, to uncover the background emission lines, along with the spatial resolution to simultaneously search for redshift matched, spatially separated images. Due to the large FoV, the position of lensed images are no longer limited to the small fibre aperture size regime. With the spectral resolution, fainter background sources may be discovered at the peak contrast between the lensed emission, and the foreground continuum. High-resolution imaging can be acquired for more detailed mass modelling, however measurements from poorer resolution IFU data has been found to match closely with <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) imaging (Collier, Smith\u00a0&amp; Lucey <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To date, almost all low-redshift lenses have been discovered with IFU observations. Two lenses, SNL-1 and SNL-2, were the subject of targeted observations with the SINFONI instrument for the SNELLS survey (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). A further lens, J0403\u22120239 (Collier, Smith\u00a0&amp; Lucey <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), was discovered within archival data from the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), with the observation taken for alternative (non-lensing) science. This lens was independently reported by Galbany et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). With the completion of current large IFU surveys [i.e. SDSS-IV Mapping Nearby Galaxies at APO (MaNGA), Sydney-AAO Multi-object Integral field spectrograph (SAMI); Bryant et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>], of order 10<sup>4</sup> ETGs will be observed, and searched for lensed images. Future surveys such as Hector (Bland-Hawthorn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) will expand this sample towards 10<sup>5</sup> galaxies. The MaNGA survey targets luminous galaxies with a low median redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.05), and with the DR14 data-release, Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) discovered one new lens, and new candidate systems were reported from a sample of 2812 galaxies by Talbot et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A key difference between the SNELLS approach and the MaNGA and SAMI surveys is the selection criteria for the targeted galaxies. SNELLS selected only the most massive ETGs as they have the largest lensing cross-sections. In doing so, the number of galaxies that must be observed to return a significant yield of lenses is greatly reduced. Although SNELLS discovered two lenses, selecting to use SINFONI for this search has limitations. The FoV of 8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec leads to highly asymmetric systems still being contaminated by FoV edge effects, see SNL-2, (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). In addition the wavelength range 1.1\u20132.45\u2009\u03bcm limits the number of emitters being probed, as only sources with redshift greater than \u223c0.7 will have strong emission lines, such as H\u2009\u03b1, in the detection range. Furthermore, there is a significant sky background incurred by working in the near-IR.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To overcome some of the limitations, we extend the technique to a wide FoV optical IFU. The MUSE nearby early-type galaxy lens locator survey (MNELLS) utilizes the 1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01 arcmin FoV to detect even the most asymmetric systems, whilst retaining a high angular resolution (0.2 arcsec<sup>2</sup>). The wavelength range of 4750\u20139300\u2009\u00c5 probes [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters up to a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.5, and Ly \u03b1 above <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a03. Here we work with data from the ESO Period 101 observations (PI: Smith). As the MUSE IFU has been in operation since 2014, we also select galaxies from the large public archive.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we report the results from our targeted and archival lens searches. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we present the sample selection for the targeted observations and those used to pick from the archive. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we present the process for identifying the emission-line sources within the datacubes. We report detections and promising candidates from the sample in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. Our lensing analysis is in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, and we assess the detection limits of our search in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.3</a>, we compare our reliability and detection limits within our observations compared to those expected and comment on implications for future searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we adopt cosmology from Planck Collaboration (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), i.e. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> =\u00a067.4\u00a0km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> =\u00a00.315, and \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> =\u00a00.685.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443552 id=\"201443552\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we outline the sample selection for the galaxies which will be used in our analysis. We describe our MUSE targeted programme in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a> and then our selection of archival MUSE observations in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443554 id=\"201443554\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Targeted sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our MUSE survey targets massive ETGs, selected by velocity dispersion, in the local Universe. These massive galaxies maximize the lensing cross-section per target, and hence increase the probability of discovering a lens. In this subsection we outline our target selection criteria.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443556 id=\"201443556\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-1>2.1.1 Target selection</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MNELLS builds upon the previous SNELLS survey, and we used the following selection criteria, similar to the earlier work:</p><ol class=\"number\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A redshift, <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.060.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A stellar velocity dispersion measured from high S/N spectra, from either the 6dFGSv (Campbell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) or SDSS (York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>); \u03c3<sub>6dF</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0300\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03c3<sub>SDSS</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0310\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, to allow for the differing fibre sizes.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy must not lie in a rich cluster/massive group environment. This prevents additional complexity in the modelling to account for either the cluster potential, or lensing effects (external shear) from other nearby massive galaxies. We judge this using the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy must be observable in ESO Period 101, April\u2013September from the very large telecope (VLT). The targets were chosen to scatter across the full right ascension range available for the semester, with a preference for southern declinations, to take advantage of the wind restrictions on northern pointings at Paranal.</p></li></ol>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443559 id=\"201443559\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1-2>2.1.2 Observations and data reduction</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE observations were undertaken in service mode (April\u2013September 2018). Each galaxy was assigned two 40\u2009min observing blocks (OBs; rotated by 45\u00b0), composed of four 380\u2009s exposures. Using wide-field no-AO mode, each frame consists of a 1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01 arcmin<sup>2</sup> FoV, with a pixel scale of 0.2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.2\u2009arcsec<sup>2</sup> and a wavelength resolution of \u223c2.7\u2009\u00c5, sampled at 1.25\u2009\u00c5\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A total of 16 candidates were observed, and of these, 14 have both OBs (i.e. full depth). The galaxies with at least one OB are shown in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Each observation was retrieved as a pipeline-reduced file as provided by ESO.</p>                        <a id=\"201443562\" scrollto-destination=\"201443562\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of the MNELLS survey. We include the exposure time, galaxy redshift, and absolute <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> magnitude. We state for each galaxy if there is a multiple- or single-imaged lensing system. Where either of these is possible, we report the distance to any emitters within 10\u2009arcsec. We use \u2018large separation\u2019 to describe systems with an emitter more distant than 6\u2009arcsec (\u223c2\u2009<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>), but within 10\u2009arcsec. Single-imaged denotes a galaxy with an emitter within 6\u2009arcsec. J13522521\u22123456009 and J15105568\u22121128477 were only observed for a single exposure.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy (2MASX)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>t</em><sub>exp</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$K_{\\rm iso}^{\\rm 2MASS}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Total emitters<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Single-imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ang. sep.\u00a0</td><td>9.7\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J21293744\u22122111443\u00a0</td><td>3060\u00a0</td><td>0.03563\u00a0</td><td>\u221226.116\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J23184637\u22121023575\u00a0</td><td>3060\u00a0</td><td>0.03170\u00a0</td><td>\u221225.347\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>Large We include the exposure time, galaxy redshift, and absolute <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> magnitude. We state for each galaxy if there is a multiple- or single-imaged lensing system. Where either of these is possible, we report the distance to any emitters within 10\u2009arcsec. We use \u2018large separation\u2019 to describe systems with an emitter more distant than 6\u2009arcsec (\u223c2\u2009<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>), but within 10\u2009arcsec. Single-imaged denotes a galaxy with an emitter within 6\u2009arcsec. J13522521\u22123456009 and J15105568\u22121128477 were only observed for a single exposure.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy (2MASX)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>t</em><sub>exp</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$K_{\\rm iso}^{\\rm 2MASS}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Total emitters<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Single-imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ang. href=\"/view-large/201443562\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443563 id=\"201443563\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MUSE archival sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">There are over 9000 existing MUSE observations publicly available. Therefore, we supplement our targeted programme with archival data. As the data already exists we relax our criteria from the very restrictive targeted selection of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> Particularly, we allow BCGs into the sample<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> as these can act as strong lenses for the same background emitters. In this subsection, we outline our selection criteria for the supplementary sample drawn from the MUSE archive.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443565 id=\"201443565\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-1>2.2.1 Target selection and observations</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to build a sample of low-<em>z</em> galaxies from the MUSE archive, we use positions, redshifts and luminosities from the 2MASS redshift survey (2MRS; Huchra et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We use the 2MRS due to its high completeness in our redshift range. We select galaxies with redshifts 0.01\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a00.07, and massive galaxies with a cut on the absolute <em>K-</em>band magnitude (as a proxy for stellar mass), at <em>K</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a0\u221225.4 mag. We show the redshift distribution of the matched galaxies against their absolute magnitude in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201443567\" scrollto-destination=\"201443567\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=qtFvYj4c7aCpb7HfCmQbaUVaIYjtjY-gzTPnwg88ziW0eBOtr~4nbixLUBdN5fnN0VsK2KChzWw93Ow2vWsSgnyRwnX~6sfoMDInO8cuMkE8c6yZFwMcY5OVpNgoz0bOZvLWFHLUhJfSy2QnRGekxUjMljYp~RVNBSexRatSUsgCInn3H7yYjJKa3J6S4y0itOP-O31oiBXU2DTSUHJ9ooRpg00-Vcg9Hw5hFaKndM14VAz-mBhc3osFrm9FRxUHDFgO2Ox9iaagIoRlJJPeeiDuj0tVTmbK-1YeISOrONTzODM0qgI6ZiKooKNrDehaYil3RAZvQCChMf9k9nqLCA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The redshift and absolute magnitude distribution of the 2MRS galaxies (background points), with those previously observed with MUSE (red, blue, and purple points). Out of those matched to the MUSE archive we exclude a large number of systems (usually due to a complex light profile, morphology or companion galaxies), in blue, and mark the selected galaxies with red points. The confirmed lens J0403\u22120239 is shown in purple.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443567/staa602fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443567\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=wh2hXB1KmY5L7ooXnuohBicP~mhUiMScZj--Sjea9M7TrC~rXdQRpivqreKjrdJmrOPyzA7lgS-mOxOGHl4d6pPU3ANDlIKOCBbfi2U-gcW~6Ai1PvNr2r9UyOBir50qQjbDdgB36vDf2NzTabrppXWJDSpQFGHQSZYpkKzniZRtP5A2tv~EzMTcSmxxkDo6mXxtgV60bl6l2yAxNyEwxvHqSs7VGDVlF~oobhCRlGjXixp71Ix0E2ignNeIjo9hzU8K-eVwa8qg1AFHs57gWBOcLeQ9s-6tXqRnYCiuQBlODojmoR-wHL9Xyab6F71Y~eq-Lw-FkMCTomDvby-Rmg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443567&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The redshift and absolute magnitude distribution of the 2MRS galaxies (background points), with those previously observed with MUSE (red, blue, and purple points). Out of those matched to the MUSE archive we exclude a large number of systems (usually due to a complex light profile, morphology or companion galaxies), in blue, and mark the selected galaxies with red points. The confirmed lens J0403\u22120239 is shown in purple.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=qtFvYj4c7aCpb7HfCmQbaUVaIYjtjY-gzTPnwg88ziW0eBOtr~4nbixLUBdN5fnN0VsK2KChzWw93Ow2vWsSgnyRwnX~6sfoMDInO8cuMkE8c6yZFwMcY5OVpNgoz0bOZvLWFHLUhJfSy2QnRGekxUjMljYp~RVNBSexRatSUsgCInn3H7yYjJKa3J6S4y0itOP-O31oiBXU2DTSUHJ9ooRpg00-Vcg9Hw5hFaKndM14VAz-mBhc3osFrm9FRxUHDFgO2Ox9iaagIoRlJJPeeiDuj0tVTmbK-1YeISOrONTzODM0qgI6ZiKooKNrDehaYil3RAZvQCChMf9k9nqLCA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The redshift and absolute magnitude distribution of the 2MRS galaxies (background points), with those previously observed with MUSE (red, blue, and purple points). Out of those matched to the MUSE archive we exclude a large number of systems (usually due to a complex light profile, morphology or companion galaxies), in blue, and mark the selected galaxies with red points. The confirmed lens J0403\u22120239 is shown in purple.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443567/staa602fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443567\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=wh2hXB1KmY5L7ooXnuohBicP~mhUiMScZj--Sjea9M7TrC~rXdQRpivqreKjrdJmrOPyzA7lgS-mOxOGHl4d6pPU3ANDlIKOCBbfi2U-gcW~6Ai1PvNr2r9UyOBir50qQjbDdgB36vDf2NzTabrppXWJDSpQFGHQSZYpkKzniZRtP5A2tv~EzMTcSmxxkDo6mXxtgV60bl6l2yAxNyEwxvHqSs7VGDVlF~oobhCRlGjXixp71Ix0E2ignNeIjo9hzU8K-eVwa8qg1AFHs57gWBOcLeQ9s-6tXqRnYCiuQBlODojmoR-wHL9Xyab6F71Y~eq-Lw-FkMCTomDvby-Rmg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443567&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The redshift and absolute magnitude distribution of the 2MRS galaxies (background points), with those previously observed with MUSE (red, blue, and purple points). Out of those matched to the MUSE archive we exclude a large number of systems (usually due to a complex light profile, morphology or companion galaxies), in blue, and mark the selected galaxies with red points. The confirmed lens J0403\u22120239 is shown in purple.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We visually inspect the MUSE collapsed datacube product, in order to exclude galaxies which would require complex lens analysis (i.e. very nearby similarly sized galaxies, or an irregular light profile). We also exclude galaxies which may have complex stellar populations (i.e. extended/strong emission and mergers), or are of a spiral morphology. Our final archival sample has 36 galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We searched all observations which were publicly available as of February 2019. We list in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, all of the investigated galaxy properties, along with the run ID and exposure times. Many of the observations were acquired by the \u2018MUSE most massive galaxy (M3G)\u2019 survey (Krajnovi\u0107 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, PI: Emsellem).</p>                        <a id=\"201443570\" scrollto-destination=\"201443570\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of our lens search within the MUSE archive. We define each galaxy by its 2MASS ID and in the second column the target object from the MUSE data header. For each galaxy we report the number of emitters, the exposure time, and if there is evidence for a multiple- or single-imaged lens system. The distance to the nearest emission-line source within 10\u2009arcsec is noted, or the distances to the multiple images. We also note two \u2018potential\u2019 systems that have single emission-line detections which we do not find compelling.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>2MASX<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Target (header)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$t_{\\rm \\exp }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Total Emitters<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Multiply imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Single imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ang. class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of our lens search within the MUSE archive. We define each galaxy by its 2MASS ID and in the second column the target object from the MUSE data header. For each galaxy we report the number of emitters, the exposure time, and if there is evidence for a multiple- or single-imaged lens system. The distance to the nearest emission-line source within 10\u2009arcsec is noted, or the distances to the multiple images. We also note two \u2018potential\u2019 systems that have single emission-line detections which we do not find compelling.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>2MASX<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Target (header)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$t_{\\rm \\exp }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Total Emitters<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Multiply imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Single imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ang. 13.2\u00a0</td><td>097.B-0766(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J20515691\u22125237473\u00a0</td><td>PGC065588\u00a0</td><td>14\u2009310\u00a0</td><td>41\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>097.B-0776(A),099.B-0148(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J23135863\u22124243393\u00a0</td><td>AS1101\u00a0</td><td>2700\u00a0</td><td>16\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Yes\u00a0</td><td>3.6\u00a0</td><td>094.A-0859(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J23363057+2108498\u00a0</td><td>A2626\u00a0</td><td>1800\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Potential\u00a0</td><td>3.5\u00a0</td><td>095.A-0159(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J23570068\u22123445331\u00a0</td><td>A4059\u00a0</td><td>10\u2009080\u00a0</td><td>33\u00a0</td><td>Yes\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>8.6, 9.8\u00a0</td><td>094.B-0592(A)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201443570\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each galaxy in the sample we select the deepest available observation, which in many cases is the MUSE-DEEP data product. The datacubes are acquired as an ESO pipeline reduced final product. The selected observations range from exposure times comparable to, or shorter than our MNELLS sample, &lt;3600 s, or much longer, &gt;10\u2009000 s and have varied seeing conditions.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443572 id=\"201443572\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 GALAXY SUBTRACTION AND EMISSION-LINE DETECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we outline our method to detect background emission-line sources. In the SNELLS survey, each datacube was visually inspected to search for background emitters. Here, we automate the process, incorporating a search algorithm as a first pass. Then we visually inspect each detection to confirm the reliability.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection process consists of two main steps: (1) the removal of the foreground lens candidate and other nearby bright continuum objects and (2) the detection and identification of emitters within the continuum-subtracted datacubes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To help isolate compact narrow emission features, we first subtract a continuum spectrum from each pixel computed using a running median with a 75\u2009\u00c5 bandwidth. The residuals from this step are next fitted with an elliptical profile computed for each wavelength channel independently, with the centre, ellipticity, and position angle fixed to match the target galaxy. When other bright sources are present in the field, their residuals are modelled similarly. This process works well except near strong spectral features in fast-rotating galaxies. After subtracting these profiles, the remaining residuals are normalized to the local standard deviation (estimated using quantiles for robustness), and smoothed with a Gaussian of 0.6\u2009arcsec full width at half-maximum (FWHM) in the spatial directions and 3.5\u2009\u00c5 FWHM in wavelength.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We developed a python-based framework for detecting emission-line features within the filtered and smoothed datacubes using routines from the <span class=\"small-caps\">scipy.ndimages.label</span> package. This package groups connected pixels above a threshold, allowing the spatially and spectrally extended peaks, due to the emission-line features, to be identified. The selection of the threshold involves a trade-off between the number of spurious detections to inspect manually, and those faint sources which may be missed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The smoothed residual datacube is separated into 40\u2009\u00c5 slices with an overlap of 5\u00c5\u2009and a labelling threshold is applied. For each labelled region, the number of pixels and the spatial extent are required to be above thresholds of 10 and 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02, respectively. Those which do not meet these criteria are not considered for further processing. These are usually artefacts from the subtraction of bright sky lines, or the lens light. If a detected source is spatially and spectrally extended, this is a strong indication of an emission line, which is then processed for identification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The candidate emitters spectrum is extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, and at \u00b1\u2009125\u2009\u00c5 around the brightest detected pixel. This range is chosen to contain [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20094959\u2009\u00c5 if the lead detection is [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20095007\u2009\u00c5, whilst avoiding H\u2009\u03b2 to simplify the emission-line fitting. (The range will also contain [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] for H\u2009\u03b1.) The extracted spectrum is then fit with a single, double and triple Gaussian, with appropriate peak ratios and separation for [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1+[N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. We perform a chi-square minimization to select the best-fitting identification and measure a redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After these detections have been carried out for each 40\u2009\u00c5 segment of the datacube, we matched detections spatially in order to combine sources with multiple emission lines at a consistent redshift, and included a step to associate the single Gaussian lines to other identified lines (generally this matches H\u2009\u03b2 to detected [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]). We do not specifically fit the asymmetric Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile, as these will be best fit with a single Gaussian with a wide FWHM, and so will be included in the sample without more complex modelling.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, the candidate lines are manually inspected and either verified as sources or rejected. Sources within a 10\u2009arcsec radius of the candidate lens centre are recorded separately. This minimizes the time per datacube on a first pass for lensed images. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show an example of the outputs which were visually inspected. Narrow-band images of the respective positions for the four strongest optical emission lines ([O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1) are displayed in the top panels. Inspecting the panels will show those detections which appear false in the spectral domain due to their lack of a clear peak, or spatial extent due to a residual (see Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">A</a> for an example of an excluded detection).</p>                        <a id=\"201443581\" scrollto-destination=\"201443581\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=LYyx3kBGUqJThrTFrQKIwqbK5SBCwC~0bvB7sOBmReOoFJKaGX5SyqMo60MXpT3iJRqqsh0qZOLcE94AoE-~~~JhCiuIxj-fwDbQQox1AjHwL5g7j8YXCntVkzAHiwfaD47YCheO18zIk9FsqytM9~cudcChDIbRCb6bERt4dzONDfvCbrfCKUlD6O7kOepZJuKASNhJ~psgX5nNb0fFSALHnSndEWGT5OMgk9xI0U0aZCNhwqnVjKOM3q25uGbAkJ1ULD9xl4uEGJYIVjKnd6zeh9GH0Zr3TNhjdPVhmtIXyoXze1vGqDPGMJS3zKSdQ-Z3S9XNp~t36KVXZBLZdw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An example emitter from an MNELLS observation. The upper panels show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009iii], and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. The panel size is 8\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, at redshift 0.3024. The emission lines extracted for the narrow-band images are indicated with the orange arrows.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443581/staa602fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443581\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=uIe1S9WECtgM-UKLZt8IRNAado3LO2LYbuLDQjLtKfpj9UR3GwCVEi1PEFxqDTBaMYTzqW6wHHj9ctcRvgb2z3nsATRv7lfdhtoaJJ1V~NO5lSh2ViJ8c2rmxLkP7BTQDhqzUJalHalmoMtE4Gj7a8lrY3Ki0c2DPHv9PhalsNJARPWJuHHW6j~2F0oXXrmmDlvTMTNmIpBoeoVb2yZgqTqftFHe4AYf~vg0l-RGb7z8LDsZTZtd6ZqPJ44ELksaYRMe2G7MmCmk~ah~-8wEonMv0jYJBo0zHnwUuZtkxZr8FfMOG2K~LAXy8lIfx~e8khVcfGCdNrQoLnadGXMtag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443581&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example emitter from an MNELLS observation.
