We select the rms for each Cartesian shear component to be <em>s</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.05 as these are galaxy lenses without significant nearby mass distributions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass maps are used to generate a grid of lensing models constrained by the position of the observed emitter. Then the number of detectable counter-images to the observed image is extracted. Following the framework outlined in Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), we estimate the probability that the system only has a single detected image, for each trial value of <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>. The results are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, with the <em>intrinsic</em> multiplicity curves showing the lensing regimes as we move from low to high <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>.</p>                        <a id=\"201443658\" scrollto-destination=\"201443658\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=l1li4TcJOv21p5yH1nOhfn4EBCwLynFvg15o7eQiSVRSHQDMQxa7e6hqBzV1vmCoir5V6sdBciQH0pl75D5jkTi29p4TgxNk7z-aMYk19Om1-QMInQjr2UZqeStkjff-jFrn67IsrXfaebaMop3Gf7~GS0FQtFJLetTXvziiTyL8n9GtSvSwnvInST9wYuIDgjlh5WmKi3Oifne2gm4wq~L3~K1VVNVZDTyfggOtmN1vpiOCAlUl2XsgvO-HXblGUttRmJAAXT92RP-mimW2s1RLOE2mlt~KxpyylYstNJU38ZZq7nPIft4CYiZ55AQ0Jl9dpdZaiRXn7Sltl0Hxsw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper-limit results for six galaxies with a single closely projected image, plotted as probability against Ks-band mass-to-light ratio (M/L). The grey lines denote the probability of not detecting a counter-image in each case. The blue/green/black lines are the fraction of intrinsic singles/doubles/quads within each M/L bin as the requirement to reproduce the observed image is met. These range from producing multiple images only at the highest of M/L, J1332\u22123146, to J0202\u22125055 which for even low M/L there are many more intrinsically multiply imaged systems. The systems J0202\u22120107 and J0202\u22125055 are constrained to have the lowest M/L in the sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443658/staa602fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443658\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=XJlYe-RBTW4yb5mcS9DJyuqOk-BQ0sMYbncdiMbSaMAXqIRIyNkz5qaRWp0zTnj4W8iqHT~Ml1iq4LV9Drfp~WcFJjW5f1VZoO1yGHZ1u8pQyXdefNdpswZ9UfPJIm6Ogwhi1mXevz6RV6X8dAtbcmhrVJs7i90g9XBJJzPLKuVabMnZI~d~NEVEAWigCuB9jii9u7hU~fJnkvC2BvcKTq~H5m6SppqBUeSDeleAgvj02veR8bJfV7LS76bP2lTCuba5Pwm0z~Wna-Bve6UlOnXCUGt4jW1kHeExdh8i1o-WS7WrYRJJiUS9dOoTAYbcE1tQlRbBVNtU4muZdA4EXw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443658&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper-limit results for six galaxies with a single closely projected image, plotted as probability against <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-band mass-to-light ratio (<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>). The grey lines denote the probability of <em>not</em> detecting a counter-image in each case. The blue/green/black lines are the fraction of intrinsic singles/doubles/quads within each <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> bin as the requirement to reproduce the observed image is met. These range from producing multiple images only at the highest of <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>, J1332\u22123146, to J0202\u22125055 which for even low <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> there are many more intrinsically multiply imaged systems. The systems J0202\u22120107 and J0202\u22125055 are constrained to have the lowest <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> in the sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=l1li4TcJOv21p5yH1nOhfn4EBCwLynFvg15o7eQiSVRSHQDMQxa7e6hqBzV1vmCoir5V6sdBciQH0pl75D5jkTi29p4TgxNk7z-aMYk19Om1-QMInQjr2UZqeStkjff-jFrn67IsrXfaebaMop3Gf7~GS0FQtFJLetTXvziiTyL8n9GtSvSwnvInST9wYuIDgjlh5WmKi3Oifne2gm4wq~L3~K1VVNVZDTyfggOtmN1vpiOCAlUl2XsgvO-HXblGUttRmJAAXT92RP-mimW2s1RLOE2mlt~KxpyylYstNJU38ZZq7nPIft4CYiZ55AQ0Jl9dpdZaiRXn7Sltl0Hxsw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper-limit results for six galaxies with a single closely projected image, plotted as probability against Ks-band mass-to-light ratio (M/L). The grey lines denote the probability of not detecting a counter-image in each case. The blue/green/black lines are the fraction of intrinsic singles/doubles/quads within each M/L bin as the requirement to reproduce the observed image is met. These range from producing multiple images only at the highest of M/L, J1332\u22123146, to J0202\u22125055 which for even low M/L there are many more intrinsically multiply imaged systems. The systems J0202\u22120107 and J0202\u22125055 are constrained to have the lowest M/L in the sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443658/staa602fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443658\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=XJlYe-RBTW4yb5mcS9DJyuqOk-BQ0sMYbncdiMbSaMAXqIRIyNkz5qaRWp0zTnj4W8iqHT~Ml1iq4LV9Drfp~WcFJjW5f1VZoO1yGHZ1u8pQyXdefNdpswZ9UfPJIm6Ogwhi1mXevz6RV6X8dAtbcmhrVJs7i90g9XBJJzPLKuVabMnZI~d~NEVEAWigCuB9jii9u7hU~fJnkvC2BvcKTq~H5m6SppqBUeSDeleAgvj02veR8bJfV7LS76bP2lTCuba5Pwm0z~Wna-Bve6UlOnXCUGt4jW1kHeExdh8i1o-WS7WrYRJJiUS9dOoTAYbcE1tQlRbBVNtU4muZdA4EXw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443658&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper-limit results for six galaxies with a single closely projected image, plotted as probability against <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-band mass-to-light ratio (<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>). The grey lines denote the probability of <em>not</em> detecting a counter-image in each case. The blue/green/black lines are the fraction of intrinsic singles/doubles/quads within each <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> bin as the requirement to reproduce the observed image is met. These range from producing multiple images only at the highest of <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>, J1332\u22123146, to J0202\u22125055 which for even low <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> there are many more intrinsically multiply imaged systems. The systems J0202\u22120107 and J0202\u22125055 are constrained to have the lowest <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> in the sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The curves display the regimes in which the background emitter is intrinsically singly imaged, then doubly imaged, quadruply imaged, and then returns to doubly imaged as the source position required to recreate the observed image moves across the caustic lines on the source plane. Additionally, we show the likelihood of there being no <em>detectable</em> counter-image for each <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> bin (i.e. including the systems that are intrinsically multiply imaged, but where the counter-images are expected to be too faint to detect). We establish the S/N limits for an undetectable counter-image by re-inserting the detected source at random positions close to the foreground galaxy with different flux scalings. Each image is then visually inspected to determine whether the source would be recovered.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As all of our quantities are derived in the <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-band, we can interpret the results with regards to a different choice of IMF via the mass-excess parameter, \u03b1 \u00a0=\u00a0(<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>)/\u03a5<sub>ref</sub>. We compare the measured <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> to a plausible range of \u03a5<sub>ref</sub> under the assumption of an old, metal rich population typical of ETGs, and adopting a Kroupa IMF. Using the Conroy, Gunn\u00a0&amp; White (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">C09</a>) models accessed with <span class=\"small-caps\">ezgal</span>, for populations of metallicity 1\u20131.5\u2009Z<sub>\u2299</sub>, and formation age 10\u201312\u2009Gyr, the sample galaxies have <em>K</em>-band \u03a5<sub>ref</sub> in the range 0.9\u2009&lt;\u03a5<sub>ref</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our choice of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">C09</a> models leads to a subtle difference between this work and Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), who used models from Maraston (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). The \u03a5<sub>ref</sub> for a Salpeter IMF tabulated by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">C09</a> and M05 agrees to within a few\u00a0per\u2009cent in the 2MASS <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>band, (for old populations with solar metallicity; see Mancone\u00a0&amp; Gonzalez <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). However, due to different treatments of the low-mass stars and the intrinsic uncertainty in the passive luminosity evolution of a galaxy, the ratio of \u03b1<sub>Kroupa</sub> and \u03b1<sub>Salpeter</sub> is different by \u223c8\u00a0per\u2009cent. Therefore in this paper for a result in agreement with a Salpeter IMF, \u03b1<sub>Kroupa</sub>\u2009\u2243\u20091.64, instead of \u22431.52. Secondly, and key, is the adopted solar absolute magnitude. The <em>K</em>-band tabulated by M05 relates to the Johnson\u2013Cousins <em>K</em>, used in Maraston (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">M98</a>), prior to the advent of the \u2018short\u2019 <em>K</em> (i.e. <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>) filter that dealt better with zero-point issues due to H<sub>2</sub>O in the atmosphere (see Bessell <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Hence, the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">M98</a>\u00a0<em>M</em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\odot }_{\\rm K}$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a03.41 is 0.115 mag offset from <em>M</em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{\\odot }_{\\rm Ks}$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a03.295, and this leads to a 11\u00a0per\u2009cent decrease in the derived luminosity when the correct value is used.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For several galaxies in this sample, the background emitter is not multiply imaged within the full range of <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>\u2009and are therefore excluded from any further analysis (J0126\u22120120, J0627\u22125426, and J1352\u22123456). In addition, from those presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, J2313\u22124243, J1332\u22123146, J0114+0025, and J1233\u22123121 are each single-imaged at masses larger than predicted by a Salpeter IMF (<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.6). Therefore, we do not make further comment on these systems in this section. However, the systems are included for investigating the ETG population in an ensemble sense, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We will now convert from <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>, to \u03b1 for the two galaxies with the strongest constraints (J0202\u22120107 and J0202\u22125055). This conversion uses \u03a5<sub>ref</sub> from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">C09</a>, for an old population, typical for low-<em>z</em> ETGs. This therefore sets an MW-like IMF to have \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.0, a Salpeter IMF to have \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.64 and we define a \u2018heavyweight\u2019 IMF with \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a02.0. We do not model the contribution from DM within the lens galaxies, therefore the \u03b1 measurements are slightly overestimated. The current low-<em>z</em> lenses have a correction of about 20\u00a0per\u2009cent (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). A system which is expected to form multiple images with a relatively light (i.e. Kroupa) IMF is a promising candidate for deeper follow up, as the observational depth is likely to be the limiting factor. In Sections <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2.1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2.2</a>, we will describe J0202\u22120107 and J0202\u22125055 respectively in reference to the IMF.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443664 id=\"201443664\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-1>5.2.1 J0202\u22120107</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J0202\u22120107 transitions from intrinsically singly\u2013 to multiply\u2013imaged for <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> between 1.25\u20131.75, see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> (top, centre right, blue and green tracks). As this source is bright, the probability of a non-detection (thick grey) follows very closely the intrinsically single-imaged (blue) track. After converting from <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> to \u03b1 it is clear for any IMF heavier than Salpeter the emitter must be intrinsically multiply imaged (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"201443666\" scrollto-destination=\"201443666\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=apfEJVs8qo1P-gmO3cYwt6L9z3l6pDZzQ4gMU5pDkiMSAzAri9FgJnVWh8sqlYYkwNAReXGij~YN4kdQorMG0vrOVqQa4gmo0lvm6h0ktanH0wjZ4emlQuAinNnnhS426-F~~WrltmmVQGHsoc4oKBbY9dkAFl~FF6v2HoateZKY6pXaQz1Vy-AkUjlGTF6CeAJtCnPs9HgmkoEaDgLI5mr0VtjSiRN5fxZ9kHE4A-f4o1u7cDi2fBU3RgnXNVVcAuyGCiCkx7RAgIk0raWMdhV7m7dOcsvd2lYyVVApbsG5fgYM8QwPX79P9~h3UQp9aUAB~7klbr3Uip4Nwp9E2w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The constraints for the upper-limit lensing analysis converted from K-band M/L to \u03b1. The grey lines show the probability of the source having no detectable counter-image. Marked along the horizontal axis are approximate bounds for different choices of IMF. The panels are labelled for the galaxy they relate to; left: J0202\u22120107, middle left/middle right/right: J0202\u22125055 inner source, outer source, and distant source.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443666/staa602fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443666\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=EfjDitD83CRhoLByt6h-BbP0FFacd5vnaO-K8d53nGj4WtPTmLULNm04ZQqXyr6KMdC~4V9q2eC0k6Z9X-Xfta53PawHuukYrg6NEz31Z594n39IlHGZ0cguqxkGm2dABFVJ5qwAVH~0e28nAphrTR1GTs-goUwyBpsOX89CrZESsU21tfaXHxKu7Lh4nvo-6dUqfm0FImnipb2PFHj3WBp3X9gVYV1rOU1ve3VOG3CS-ode92G~iWi-1bcI96v9cVg3sWGPLXqt7pMz15rhvFqlXkP8K7~RqY0659dpr0d76rGO9f8KDkzbgWyt07Z2d8JcoDH3NBIFiZROueloUg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443666&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The constraints for the upper-limit lensing analysis converted from <em>K</em>-band <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> to \u03b1. The grey lines show the probability of the source having no <em>detectable</em> counter-image. Marked along the horizontal axis are approximate bounds for different choices of IMF. The panels are labelled for the galaxy they relate to; <em>left:</em> J0202\u22120107, <em>middle left/middle right/right:</em> J0202\u22125055 inner source, outer source, and distant source.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=apfEJVs8qo1P-gmO3cYwt6L9z3l6pDZzQ4gMU5pDkiMSAzAri9FgJnVWh8sqlYYkwNAReXGij~YN4kdQorMG0vrOVqQa4gmo0lvm6h0ktanH0wjZ4emlQuAinNnnhS426-F~~WrltmmVQGHsoc4oKBbY9dkAFl~FF6v2HoateZKY6pXaQz1Vy-AkUjlGTF6CeAJtCnPs9HgmkoEaDgLI5mr0VtjSiRN5fxZ9kHE4A-f4o1u7cDi2fBU3RgnXNVVcAuyGCiCkx7RAgIk0raWMdhV7m7dOcsvd2lYyVVApbsG5fgYM8QwPX79P9~h3UQp9aUAB~7klbr3Uip4Nwp9E2w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The constraints for the upper-limit lensing analysis converted from K-band M/L to \u03b1. The grey lines show the probability of the source having no detectable counter-image. Marked along the horizontal axis are approximate bounds for different choices of IMF. The panels are labelled for the galaxy they relate to; left: J0202\u22120107, middle left/middle right/right: J0202\u22125055 inner source, outer source, and distant source.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443666/staa602fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443666\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=EfjDitD83CRhoLByt6h-BbP0FFacd5vnaO-K8d53nGj4WtPTmLULNm04ZQqXyr6KMdC~4V9q2eC0k6Z9X-Xfta53PawHuukYrg6NEz31Z594n39IlHGZ0cguqxkGm2dABFVJ5qwAVH~0e28nAphrTR1GTs-goUwyBpsOX89CrZESsU21tfaXHxKu7Lh4nvo-6dUqfm0FImnipb2PFHj3WBp3X9gVYV1rOU1ve3VOG3CS-ode92G~iWi-1bcI96v9cVg3sWGPLXqt7pMz15rhvFqlXkP8K7~RqY0659dpr0d76rGO9f8KDkzbgWyt07Z2d8JcoDH3NBIFiZROueloUg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443666&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The constraints for the upper-limit lensing analysis converted from <em>K</em>-band <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> to \u03b1. The grey lines show the probability of the source having no <em>detectable</em> counter-image. Marked along the horizontal axis are approximate bounds for different choices of IMF. The panels are labelled for the galaxy they relate to; <em>left:</em> J0202\u22120107, <em>middle left/middle right/right:</em> J0202\u22125055 inner source, outer source, and distant source.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">If we compare our 50\u00a0per\u2009cent probability cut-off to that reported in Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), this result is 20\u00a0per\u2009cent larger. The revised solar absolute magnitude contributes to a 12\u00a0per\u2009cent increase. The remaining difference must originate from other modelling uncertainty. In the earlier paper, we fitted a de Vaucouleurs profile (<em>n</em>\u00a0=\u00a04) to a Pan-STARRS <em>y</em>-band image and scaled the resulting model to a 5\u2009arcsec aperture 2MASS <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> flux. We now instead fit directly to VISTA <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-band imaging, and allow a free S\u00e9rsic parameter. This leads to a difference of 0.05\u2009mags between the apparent magnitude here using the de-convolved <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> model, compared to the PSF-corrected measurement from 2MASS (due to the much larger 2MASS PSF). Finally, our cosmology leads to a 3\u00a0per\u2009cent change, with an increased <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> value. Therefore, the changes in how the lens light is modelled and the cosmology account for the difference relative to the earlier work.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443668 id=\"201443668\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-2>5.2.2 J0202\u22125055</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The nearest three emitters in the J0202\u22125055 system are displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. We do not consider the effect of multiple-plane lensing for any of the sources. The source with the smallest separation is also at the lowest redshift, so there is no multiplane effect in this case. In principal there is an impact on the other two sources from those preceding in redshift, but the effects are likely negligible because the lensed galaxies are likely to be very low mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The inner source is separated from the galaxy centre by 1.92\u2009arcsec with <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u20090.29, and the outer source is separated by 3.4\u2009arcsec, at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u20091.29. The inner source is expected to be <em>intrinsically</em> multiply imaged even for stellar populations described by <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>\u00a0=\u20091. As the source is faint, and the probability for a non-detection is low in the quad regime, and a small tail at <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2\u20131.5. Hence the depth of our observation is the limiting factor for a non-detection of a counter-image for this source. The second source is more distant, and hence can be intrinsically single-imaged for more massive systems up to <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>\u2009\u2243\u20091.1\u20131.3.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As with J0202\u22120107, we convert from <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> to \u03b1 in order to investigate this system with respect to the IMF (See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>). If the foreground galaxy formed with an IMF consistent with Kroupa, the first source should be multiply imaged, but the second and third sources are likely not. If we consider a Salpeter IMF, or an \u03b1 consistent with that predicted from Atlas3D (\u223c1.5, Cappellari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), the first and second source are intrinsically multiply imaged. A galaxy forming with a \u2018heavyweight\u2019 IMF may even produce counter-images for all three sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">J0202\u22125055 offers a promising system for further observations, as for any reasonable IMF parametrization a deeper observation is likely to unveil a counter-image to the innermost source. Analysis can then constrain \u03b1, using the same technique as the other low-<em>z</em> systems (i.e. J0403\u22120239 in Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). In addition, the second faint source, separated by 3.4\u2009arcsec, offers a potential double source-plane if the lens IMF is even modestly heavier than Kroupa (including DM).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443673 id=\"201443673\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-3>5.2.3 Summary</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of the nine apparently single-imaged systems presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, analysis showed two systems that likely have faint counter-images for even a low <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> lens (J0202\u22120107 and J0202\u22125055, see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). However, more detailed analysis shows that J0202\u22120107 cannot rule out having formed with a moderately heavy IMF (\u03b1; 1.25\u20131.75). This range is consistent with the \u03b1-versus-\u03c3 relation measured with stellar dynamics by Cappellari et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), which predicts \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3 for \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0264\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. For J0202\u22125055, if the lens forms with an IMF consistent with the \u03b1-versus-\u03c3 relation, then a double source plane lens will be discovered with deeper observations. If confirmed by future observations, J0202\u22125055 will be one of only a handful of known double source-plane systems.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443675 id=\"201443675\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 The Lens Population</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>intrinsic</em> distribution of the IMF within ETGs can be inferred from the four confirmed low-<em>z</em> lenses (taking values for SNL-0, SNL-1, SNL-2, J0403\u22120239 from Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). We have shown in Collier et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) that for a normal distribution with a flat prior on the mean and marginalizing over the intrinsic scatter, \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.09\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08. Alternatively, by marginalizing over the mean, the 90\u00a0per\u2009cent upper limit on the standard deviation of \u03b1 is 0.32 (29\u00a0per\u2009cent). However, if there is a sizeable scatter in the IMF within the ETG population, then the lensing systems are likely to be biased towards those with the highest mass. This was found by Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), who compared the SLACS lens population to weak lensing of non-strong-lensing ETGs. Therefore combining the \u2018upper limits\u2019 and the confirmed lenses may better constrain the <em>ensemble</em> population (see also Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Here, we use seven of the nine upper limit systems presented in this paper, (due to the lack of constraint even at the top of our <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> range, we do not include J0627\u22125426 and J1352\u22123456). We add the two systems analysed in Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) from other surveys (SNL-4 and J0728+4005) along with the four confirmed lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We model the intrinsic population as a lognormal (base <em>e</em>) distribution in \u03b1, described with a mean, \u2329\u03b1\u232a and an intrinsic scatter \u03bd, as currently there are too few systems to constrain the shape of the distribution. Modelling \u03b1 with a normal distribution does not significantly affect the results. We set flat priors on \u2329\u03b1\u232a and \u03bd, between [0,\u20092.5] and [0,\u20090.5] respectively. We derive the probability of each \u03b1 value, given either a confirmed lens, or the upper-limit analysis, see the shaded regions in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11(a)</a>. Systems alike to J0202\u22125055, which have tight upper limits on \u03b1 <em>comparable</em> with those measured from confirmed lenses, offer the most information.</p>                        <a id=\"201443678\" scrollto-destination=\"201443678\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=X2yxb5qW2Ql6AR5eqRLhFDjWNuZba2AAWGpUqjWTid-xKxf~PioNDfEpyxRrRyKkid2~d2SF4x8OVonj7TDeyz5Kev~NyD98-F5b~Il-JFSR2jzXWY-DOfIOZ9DQs4Yc-ZRlLvXewnTcBOp6YK~RrQIrELCAqV4RE642KkgiT8QkIl00WqWs40XbpUgDijFaAF1D7t5Z6EAPFMLjpa1upxGPE9sdAmo2KvtLaDVuF6GgvtW1mkYvqM~Y9z3P8~U1qYLiJD8VvhljAu-UlQpQzDRjBgSGKF~SH8EHDHffpQc6w6C6sfgSRqvRtRcMoyUOQGUPKw1ejYvEzcF~YAYGCA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The distribution of \u03b1 for the population of both lenses and single-imaged systems. Values calculated with just the four lenses are in blue, the four lenses combined with the upper-limit analysis is green, and removing J0403\u22120239, leaving three lenses and the upper limits is displayed in orange. (a) The lenses and upper-limit intrinsic population in \u03b1. The shaded background regions show the probability of a given alpha for the lenses (lowest four), or upper-limit analysis. (d) Contours showing the distribution in \u2329\u03b1\u232a and \u03bd (the intrinsic scatter) space with and without the upper limits. The twist to lower \u03b1 at higher \u03bd can clearly be seen. (c) The intrinsic distribution in \u03b1 as we change the sample. Removing a the lens J0403\u22120239 has the largest effect, and shifts the distribution to favour lower \u03b1. Adding the upper limits shifts the peak of the distribution to lower \u03b1, compared to just the lenses. This is due to the significant effect of J0202\u22123055. (d) The predicted intrinsic scatter of the distribution in base e, with dashed lines at the 90\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence interval for each case. As can be seen, adding the upper limits favours a population with a smaller scatter, than just the lenses. Removing J0403\u22120239 and including the upper-limits increase the intrinsic scatter significantly (30\u00a0per\u2009cent).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443678/staa602fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443678\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=M3PKuSDpw8OoNFf9OyWPMdskdJxkduPGrd53FxgjAqsWw98d1nlxomFP7HTBGgPMZ3GUoFaJbBDh~fK4qQzmfjoEgbYz0MgSvWXGsSrk128wKFYVayxYYDynHsQ5YiNP1R3VRdRCKMS9jd0YsAUhql00sFjF61VE1XhuF7XvMYcqRvq9A1LEQ8zpWMmMgdCjDphUX1nsSIO86Bk1dz-rx8W4dGQGUf2FrZy7tLvPXhnsFK7UMjdCSFt0REzm1xguDwZxEXLxwZlRN6x3q6VjOtG~E~Msn3zm9kMdV6Ss0VX4ffl9Lonflqj9nNFPKZWc6~g1Ose3TeBh3KysuJPr3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443678&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution of \u03b1 for the population of both lenses and single-imaged systems. Values calculated with just the four lenses are in blue, the four lenses combined with the upper-limit analysis is green, and removing J0403\u22120239, leaving three lenses and the upper limits is displayed in orange. (a) The lenses and upper-limit intrinsic population in \u03b1. The shaded background regions show the probability of a given alpha for the lenses (lowest four), or upper-limit analysis. (d) Contours showing the distribution in \u2329\u03b1\u232a and \u03bd (the intrinsic scatter) space with and without the upper limits. The twist to lower \u03b1 at higher \u03bd can clearly be seen. (c) The intrinsic distribution in \u03b1 as we change the sample. Removing a the lens J0403\u22120239 has the largest effect, and shifts the distribution to favour lower \u03b1. Adding the upper limits shifts the peak of the distribution to lower \u03b1, compared to just the lenses. This is due to the significant effect of J0202\u22123055. (d) The predicted intrinsic scatter of the distribution in base <em>e</em>, with dashed lines at the 90\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence interval for each case. As can be seen, adding the upper limits favours a population with a smaller scatter, than just the lenses. Removing J0403\u22120239 and including the upper-limits increase the intrinsic scatter significantly (30\u00a0per\u2009cent).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=X2yxb5qW2Ql6AR5eqRLhFDjWNuZba2AAWGpUqjWTid-xKxf~PioNDfEpyxRrRyKkid2~d2SF4x8OVonj7TDeyz5Kev~NyD98-F5b~Il-JFSR2jzXWY-DOfIOZ9DQs4Yc-ZRlLvXewnTcBOp6YK~RrQIrELCAqV4RE642KkgiT8QkIl00WqWs40XbpUgDijFaAF1D7t5Z6EAPFMLjpa1upxGPE9sdAmo2KvtLaDVuF6GgvtW1mkYvqM~Y9z3P8~U1qYLiJD8VvhljAu-UlQpQzDRjBgSGKF~SH8EHDHffpQc6w6C6sfgSRqvRtRcMoyUOQGUPKw1ejYvEzcF~YAYGCA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The distribution of \u03b1 for the population of both lenses and single-imaged systems. Values calculated with just the four lenses are in blue, the four lenses combined with the upper-limit analysis is green, and removing J0403\u22120239, leaving three lenses and the upper limits is displayed in orange. (a) The lenses and upper-limit intrinsic population in \u03b1. The shaded background regions show the probability of a given alpha for the lenses (lowest four), or upper-limit analysis. (d) Contours showing the distribution in \u2329\u03b1\u232a and \u03bd (the intrinsic scatter) space with and without the upper limits. The twist to lower \u03b1 at higher \u03bd can clearly be seen. (c) The intrinsic distribution in \u03b1 as we change the sample. Removing a the lens J0403\u22120239 has the largest effect, and shifts the distribution to favour lower \u03b1. Adding the upper limits shifts the peak of the distribution to lower \u03b1, compared to just the lenses. This is due to the significant effect of J0202\u22123055. (d) The predicted intrinsic scatter of the distribution in base e, with dashed lines at the 90\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence interval for each case. As can be seen, adding the upper limits favours a population with a smaller scatter, than just the lenses. Removing J0403\u22120239 and including the upper-limits increase the intrinsic scatter significantly (30\u00a0per\u2009cent).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443678/staa602fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443678\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=M3PKuSDpw8OoNFf9OyWPMdskdJxkduPGrd53FxgjAqsWw98d1nlxomFP7HTBGgPMZ3GUoFaJbBDh~fK4qQzmfjoEgbYz0MgSvWXGsSrk128wKFYVayxYYDynHsQ5YiNP1R3VRdRCKMS9jd0YsAUhql00sFjF61VE1XhuF7XvMYcqRvq9A1LEQ8zpWMmMgdCjDphUX1nsSIO86Bk1dz-rx8W4dGQGUf2FrZy7tLvPXhnsFK7UMjdCSFt0REzm1xguDwZxEXLxwZlRN6x3q6VjOtG~E~Msn3zm9kMdV6Ss0VX4ffl9Lonflqj9nNFPKZWc6~g1Ose3TeBh3KysuJPr3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443678&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution of \u03b1 for the population of both lenses and single-imaged systems. Values calculated with just the four lenses are in blue, the four lenses combined with the upper-limit analysis is green, and removing J0403\u22120239, leaving three lenses and the upper limits is displayed in orange. (a) The lenses and upper-limit intrinsic population in \u03b1. The shaded background regions show the probability of a given alpha for the lenses (lowest four), or upper-limit analysis. (d) Contours showing the distribution in \u2329\u03b1\u232a and \u03bd (the intrinsic scatter) space with and without the upper limits. The twist to lower \u03b1 at higher \u03bd can clearly be seen. (c) The intrinsic distribution in \u03b1 as we change the sample. Removing a the lens J0403\u22120239 has the largest effect, and shifts the distribution to favour lower \u03b1. Adding the upper limits shifts the peak of the distribution to lower \u03b1, compared to just the lenses. This is due to the significant effect of J0202\u22123055. (d) The predicted intrinsic scatter of the distribution in base <em>e</em>, with dashed lines at the 90\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence interval for each case. As can be seen, adding the upper limits favours a population with a smaller scatter, than just the lenses. Removing J0403\u22120239 and including the upper-limits increase the intrinsic scatter significantly (30\u00a0per\u2009cent).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each confirmed lens, we estimate the likelihood of drawing \u03b1<sub>meas</sub> from the intrinsic population, <em>P</em>(\u03b1|\u2329\u03b1\u232a, \u03bd) with a broadening on \u03bd from the uncertainty in the measurement. A grid based exploration of \u2329\u03b1\u232a, and \u03bd with step size 0.01, produces the dashed contours shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11(b)</a>. The intrinsic distribution marginalized over \u03bd has a \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.07\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11(c)</a>, which is consistent with the result of \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.09\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 from Collier et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) for the same lenses.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To include the upper limits a slightly more complex approach is required. The probability of a given \u2329\u03b1\u232a, \u03bd combination (<em>P<sub>i</sub></em>(\u2329\u03b1\u232a, \u03bd)) is now given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nP_i(\\langle \\alpha \\rangle ,\\nu)\\, =\\, \\int U(\\alpha _i) P(\\alpha _i | \\langle \\alpha \\rangle ,\\nu) \\mathrm{ d}\\alpha _i ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where <em>U</em>(\u03b1<sub><em>i</em></sub>) is the likelihood for a galaxy to have a given \u03b1 (in the range [0,\u20093.0]), from the \u2018upper limit\u2019 analysis. This is related to <em>U</em>(<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>) by a convolution with a Gaussian uncertainty contributed by \u03a5<sub>ref</sub>. Including this likelihood allows us to marginalize over the unknown true value of \u03b1 for each galaxy.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution from the upper limits alone is strongly skewed towards low \u2329\u03b1\u232a. Therefore combining this with the confirmed lenses, skews the overall distribution towards lower \u2329\u03b1\u232a (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11c</a>). It also reduces the scatter \u03bd. The combined distribution has a mean of 1.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11(a)</a>. The 90\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence upper limit on the standard deviation of \u03b1 is 0.24 (20\u00a0per\u2009cent). This is a nine\u00a0per\u2009cent decrease compared to using only the four confirmed lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We consider what finding additional single-imaged galaxies might do to the distribution by testing the addition of hypothetical systems consistent with those presented in this paper. If we add new fake systems consistent with J2313\u22124243, we find that these do not change \u2329\u03b1\u232a or \u03bd. However, adding four hypothetical systems alike to J0202\u22120107, where the 20\u00a0per\u2009cent probability for a non-detected counter-image lies at \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.5, reduces the inferred intrinsic scatter in the population, without changing \u2329\u03b1\u232a. Finally, additional hypothetical systems consistent with J0202\u22125055 and J0728+4005 will <em>increase</em> \u03bd and <em>reduce</em> \u2329\u03b1\u232a, as the upper limits suggest that they formed with IMFs lighter than \u2329\u03b1\u232a predicted from only the confirmed lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our analysis demonstrates that the strong-lens systems favour a comparably heavier IMF than those systems which include only a single emitter. The population of low-<em>z</em> strong lenses are offset by 8 per cent from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M/L$|</span> predicted by a Kroupa IMF. However, these are biased towards a higher <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha$|\u2060</span>, and the distribution will have a smaller mean. Hence the <em>ensemble</em> population lies in closer agreement with the Kroupa IMF. Our distribution of \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 is within 3\u03c3 of similar attempts to combine strong-lensing constraints with other independent techniques (e.g. Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), who found \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a00.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443684 id=\"201443684\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 THE MNELLS SEARCH EFFICIENCY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we will assess the MNELLS programme technique. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.1</a>, we test the flux detection threshold as a function of wavelength, and then of distance from the centre of the target galaxy. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2</a>, we determine the number density of background emitters in our data set. Then in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.3</a>, we discuss potential modifications to the observing strategy, and contrast our technique to the MaNGA survey.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443686 id=\"201443686\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Detection threshold with artificial point sources</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The flux detection limit for a background source is the key parameter for assessing the efficiency of the MNELLS observing setup. This will test whether the true observed depth matches our expectation based on other surveys and inform plans for future observing campaigns.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compute the recovery fractions by injecting fake point sources, convolved to a representative psf, into a real datacube. There is scatter in the sky background from galaxy to galaxy, so we select J2318\u22121023 which contains few other bright emitters and has noise properties representative of the median of our sample. Each source is modelled with a Gaussian with an FWHM of 5\u2009\u00c5 and a spatial FWHM matched to the datacube seeing of 0.8\u2009arcsec, typical for an emission line within our survey. A total of 16 sources are injected into to the datacube as a 4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a04 source grid, with a subpixel scatter applied to each position in both the spatial and spectral dimensions. For each wavelength and flux we applied nine dithers to the grid. The sources are then scaled to total fluxes ranging from 10<sup>\u221215.25</sup> to 10<sup>\u221218.5</sup>\u2009erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, in steps of 0.25 dex.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We perform this test for four wavelength channels which are representative of the typical noise situations for the background emitters. The channels are chosen as 5000, 6861.25, 7100, and 7242.5\u2009\u00c5, which cover the blue, less sensitive region of the datacube (5000\u2009\u00c5), a mid-way low sky noise region (7100\u2009\u00c5), and then two regions of the datacube close to sky lines. These are selected to match the wavelengths used in equivalent analysis by Herenz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For each cube with simulated sources the full processing and emission line detection is carried out, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, and the recovery fractions are measured.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The most sensitive of these channels is the 7100\u2009\u00c5 channel, with a 90\u00a0per\u2009cent threshold of \u223c10<sup>\u221216.15</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. In contrast, the bluest channel (5000\u2009\u00c5) has a significantly lower sensitivity, \u223c0.4 dex offset from 7100\u2009\u00c5\u2009; see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. This is likely due to a high lunar continuum, i.e. a high fraction of lunar illumination (FLI), which ranges up to 0.9, during the time of our observations. Note that in practice, the impact of a low detection threshold in blue channels could be reduced as the emission lines detected in the blue are mainly low-<em>z</em> [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters. These may still be identified from strong [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1 lines, which will be present in lower background redder channels. The only lines with no strong counterparts in the cleaner spectrum are Ly \u03b1 emitters.</p>                        <a id=\"201443691\" scrollto-destination=\"201443691\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=sJ9Gicr8B~I10ZHyULqPeNQk2p0YGBNWRUuHdRENaDjt29guGNWd3QqMGv5PvuDr08MkMsQgdQFChBvgIavePKRyo2NiNEB5k0pV~wqmjoDiaGTQ5csTntRlZhvLAOHppnfJzKYtHZXnX7dlUOxBuTnlaApIUXQk-e~KMbNnqSqEG~EqdkOjSFl7BCAnaHO5~9zr3D1Z5ZxfqpgoYjTyTBA0BvaqFmOmqBzNkSGxp~1RrL7eC619xQJV739xHLpfyCYhLg8ctLdva77zt4xvrl8FFNM4rTO0OXDjjgaQsGICQSL90ng2KQ9dJdLhXNmK8uCSG8LQDtzUJRmjSoEWZg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Recovery fraction detected/injected, from the insertion and detection of fake point sources for four different wavelengths within a single MUSE datacube. The detection process follows that used for the targeted observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443691/staa602fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443691\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=x7YjlYGtfvypm4BU9jH0aU6fbI95C1Gjj3Ne8N7kP8X7f6IB5w2Pgp7W2tAzmo~SAXIvHpR8AjkU4BSLlEUkt7iUWBhTwdvdIlmInmwwS6kfQ8rAuWxCuyKHF3D9OguM8UTRa5opkUtk3bQlWIV0YdyVeY5hEieNfZKbUiSi-LkvDz-YoyfFu~xNpOwQp3i~qx7tSuIswQFeyy2HtrdGqqQh-7V62COIS3VDJ0x2fOoH6E8L9JJzqnxvgDNDG1TsHjXwGuo~ck8JJvthZnyJceX74v9J26nRd-XwI2or9kqjVThKqC~C23B031-oZwZ4ZfxESOXN2TNldRdYhlLx9w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443691&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recovery fraction detected/injected, from the insertion and detection of fake point sources for four different wavelengths within a single MUSE datacube. The detection process follows that used for the targeted observations.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=sJ9Gicr8B~I10ZHyULqPeNQk2p0YGBNWRUuHdRENaDjt29guGNWd3QqMGv5PvuDr08MkMsQgdQFChBvgIavePKRyo2NiNEB5k0pV~wqmjoDiaGTQ5csTntRlZhvLAOHppnfJzKYtHZXnX7dlUOxBuTnlaApIUXQk-e~KMbNnqSqEG~EqdkOjSFl7BCAnaHO5~9zr3D1Z5ZxfqpgoYjTyTBA0BvaqFmOmqBzNkSGxp~1RrL7eC619xQJV739xHLpfyCYhLg8ctLdva77zt4xvrl8FFNM4rTO0OXDjjgaQsGICQSL90ng2KQ9dJdLhXNmK8uCSG8LQDtzUJRmjSoEWZg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Recovery fraction detected/injected, from the insertion and detection of fake point sources for four different wavelengths within a single MUSE datacube. The detection process follows that used for the targeted observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443691/staa602fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443691\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=x7YjlYGtfvypm4BU9jH0aU6fbI95C1Gjj3Ne8N7kP8X7f6IB5w2Pgp7W2tAzmo~SAXIvHpR8AjkU4BSLlEUkt7iUWBhTwdvdIlmInmwwS6kfQ8rAuWxCuyKHF3D9OguM8UTRa5opkUtk3bQlWIV0YdyVeY5hEieNfZKbUiSi-LkvDz-YoyfFu~xNpOwQp3i~qx7tSuIswQFeyy2HtrdGqqQh-7V62COIS3VDJ0x2fOoH6E8L9JJzqnxvgDNDG1TsHjXwGuo~ck8JJvthZnyJceX74v9J26nRd-XwI2or9kqjVThKqC~C23B031-oZwZ4ZfxESOXN2TNldRdYhlLx9w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443691&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recovery fraction detected/injected, from the insertion and detection of fake point sources for four different wavelengths within a single MUSE datacube. The detection process follows that used for the targeted observations.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For comparison to these results, we have performed the same fake source injection into a MUSE-Wide datacube. We reach a threshold \u223c0.5 dex fainter (at 7100\u2009\u00c5) with this data. The difference originates from the sky background due to their observations taking place in dark time. After the ETG is filtered, the MNELLS background is on average three times higher, with the most significant difference seen at 5000\u2009\u00c5 (due to the high FLI), and the weakest at 7242.5\u2009\u00c5 where the noise is instead dominated by a bright sky line.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our search is designed to target sources which are close to the centre of a foreground galaxy. Hence we incur a much larger contribution to the noise than just the sky background at small lens-source angular separation. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> shows the detection limit for the 7100\u2009\u00c5 channel as a function of radius. Within 6\u2009arcsec of the galaxy centre (\u223c2\u2009<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>), the flux threshold is typically 0.35 dex brighter than the full FoV. Beyond a radius of 10\u2009arcsec the sensitivity shows no strong radial dependence.</p>                        <a id=\"201443694\" scrollto-destination=\"201443694\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=gDfHcJI13Ke4-Kar0JkVSjm2tn-nGbTS7v1VWxxems9U92eupTdJPhErLgQdQjWevSWzeIra2y0GxX1P51A1~hTkXZHbbLNuaA763BqJanJ-j1PVpckNdz~v1bwAFn3qwABIANDAwtzyc8ZW7V6PxKJAQcgzqj3uxoN-Wo9AUbzefb2WZdCyIo5m70KDsKkqKYjH2GqNIiXLNmD5RJwP9oc2ntVjn4XkiqUAgeu1Ytmn1iRK~EwCFymUok2Qjj-Ks4lBZrLmoHyWSjFohfpt5OhLgHY7nDpgqXQqevTAibCvZgBWY8nLaWaiM8dRvvf2t9Q56Aw3nvJN6YlDgfnymQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a012 (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2REin is marked with a dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443694/staa602fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443694\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=VQVu6xYFom9-j3BB94Msvgww1a9gS99gm~lIQv~mMNlQpNmSONrxcbYjfW-rXkTV8c3F4MWakJTfLsqYA6tzAO23poaqjNwB7bmGX7zhSHLVhgqKX0NNXncbR9JyaB4QO-LBEE1tRS99Ssy1bhDN65WKKKc8Oko20cS8h3g32lMTVEsj4shAmdxze6Ft7iztrc76hOVeOasm~qZUbR9-pyf055iWlOR5y8aQvW8bvMuDqNuwTR6ZLel5hptOnQwH46m2EEBKCBKHTaBtL4QDb7zVRvrN3lxVO6J8PMwxA5tARxE25~gtnUFSgr8HyVtBar1rFUGPNIEsjprvhoDfSQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443694&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> is marked with a dashed line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=gDfHcJI13Ke4-Kar0JkVSjm2tn-nGbTS7v1VWxxems9U92eupTdJPhErLgQdQjWevSWzeIra2y0GxX1P51A1~hTkXZHbbLNuaA763BqJanJ-j1PVpckNdz~v1bwAFn3qwABIANDAwtzyc8ZW7V6PxKJAQcgzqj3uxoN-Wo9AUbzefb2WZdCyIo5m70KDsKkqKYjH2GqNIiXLNmD5RJwP9oc2ntVjn4XkiqUAgeu1Ytmn1iRK~EwCFymUok2Qjj-Ks4lBZrLmoHyWSjFohfpt5OhLgHY7nDpgqXQqevTAibCvZgBWY8nLaWaiM8dRvvf2t9Q56Aw3nvJN6YlDgfnymQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a012 (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2REin is marked with a dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443694/staa602fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443694\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=VQVu6xYFom9-j3BB94Msvgww1a9gS99gm~lIQv~mMNlQpNmSONrxcbYjfW-rXkTV8c3F4MWakJTfLsqYA6tzAO23poaqjNwB7bmGX7zhSHLVhgqKX0NNXncbR9JyaB4QO-LBEE1tRS99Ssy1bhDN65WKKKc8Oko20cS8h3g32lMTVEsj4shAmdxze6Ft7iztrc76hOVeOasm~qZUbR9-pyf055iWlOR5y8aQvW8bvMuDqNuwTR6ZLel5hptOnQwH46m2EEBKCBKHTaBtL4QDb7zVRvrN3lxVO6J8PMwxA5tARxE25~gtnUFSgr8HyVtBar1rFUGPNIEsjprvhoDfSQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443694&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> is marked with a dashed line.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443695 id=\"201443695\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Number density of background emitters</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this subsection we consider the number density of background emitters actually detected within our targeted observations. We also compare to the MUSE-Wide for our measured flux threshold. As described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>, the MNELLS observations are shallow exposures taken in poor seeing conditions. In our calculations, we only include the 14 fields that have the full exposure time; in total these fields have 164 detected emitters. The average full depth area within a combined datacube is 0.92 square arcmin, therefore the median number density of emitters within our full depth observations is 12.7 per square arcmin; the field-to-field standard deviation is 5.5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The full depth MUSE-wide survey reaches a number density of 37.4 emitters per square arcmin. In comparison with MNELLS, each observation is 20\u00a0per\u2009cent longer (a 1\u2009hr exposure), in conditions with a lower sky background (observed in dark/grey time instead of grey/bright). So, using their figure 13, and with our cut off at a depth of 10<sup>\u221216.1</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup> (for 90\u00a0per\u2009cent to be detected), we would predict 6.3 emitters per square arcmin. The number density from our MUSE data (12.7 arcmin<sup>\u22122</sup>) is actually twice this. The detection threshold which aligns these two values is a flux limit of 10<sup>\u221216.5</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. From Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, this suggests we should adopt a 60\u00a0per\u2009cent detection limit to align our numbers with the MUSE-Wide.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the central 6\u2009arcsec where the detection threshold for 60\u00a0per\u2009cent recovery (to match the achieved number density of emitters) is 10<sup>\u221216.15</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, the MUSE-wide predicted number count is 6.3 arcmin<sup>\u22122</sup> (an 80\u00a0per\u2009cent decrease). For the average targeted galaxy, the strong lensing regime encompasses 23 square arcsec (\u03c0<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub><sup>2</sup>; <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.9\u2009arcsec). The resulting probability for a lens galaxy having a detectable multiply imaged source is 0.04. So we expect one in 25 observed galaxies will exhibit a multiply imaged background source. Note that the counter-images may be fainter than the detection threshold.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443699 id=\"201443699\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 Considerations for future MNELLS-like surveys</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The MNELLS project observational constraints (e.g. no moon constraints) were selected to maximize the number of executed observations by taking advantage of underused observatory conditions, under the assumption that the ETG will dominate the background. We predict the number of lenses to be one in every 25 full depth observations, and in calculating this we uncovered a few key contributions affecting our detection limits which need to be considered for future targeted surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The background noise from the lunar continuum, and sky brightness has clearly affected our detection limits. The variable observing conditions (specifically the FLI and sky background) may provide a simple explanation for the origin of the large field-to-field scatter in the number of detected emitters, independent of the lens light. In addition the subtraction of the ETG also negatively impacts the detection threshold. Hence, these two effects (higher background, and lens subtraction) reduce our detection threshold compared to the MUSE-Wide survey by almost 0.5 dex. The centre of the datacube is less sensitive to faint emitters, which cannot be avoided, but at shorter wavelengths we are also offset by 0.4 dex from channels less affected by the lunar continuum. For future surveys, as a trade-off for the number of observations, a tighter constraint on the moon illumination may be considered to reduce the sky background.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to altering the observing conditions, we can consider an alternative selection method, which may improve the likelihood of a lens discovery. Our current selection criteria (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>) uses a single-fibre velocity dispersion as a proxy for stellar mass, and hence <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>. Instead we could directly measure <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> from a mass-follows-light profile, (such as those used in our upper-limit lensing calculations), and select galaxies to maximize the lensing cross-section. However, using the light profile measured <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> as a part of the selection process introduces additional computation, which will require additional cuts in parameter space to be efficient. Instead the current technique is considerably simpler, and the <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> scales with the velocity dispersion (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An alternative to the \u2018targeted\u2019 blind search methods like MNELLS is to exploit large IFU surveys. For example the MaNGA survey (Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) has a sample median redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, z\\, \\rangle$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a00.05 (100\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> &lt;\u03c3\u2009&lt; 400\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>), which is comparable to MNELLS. The full MaNGA survey will take IFU observations of over 10\u2009000 ETGs and hence will discover a number of low-<em>z</em> strong gravitational lenses. To date, Talbot et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) worked with a sample of 2812 ETGs, and so far has produced 2\u20136 candidate lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although MaNGA\u2019s median redshift is comparable to that of MNELLS, it aims to observe a broad range of galaxy sizes, including a high fraction of low-\u03c3 ETGs. The larger (higher-\u03c3) ETGs typically lie more distant than their median redshift, so that the same fraction of <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> is imaged within the FoV (See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). This has two implications: First, the low-<em>z</em>, low-\u03c3 galaxies are less likely to be gravitational strong lenses so the number of discovered lenses is likely reduced. Secondly, the higher \u03c3 galaxies which are more likely to be lenses lie and higher redshift and are hence subject to larger DM uncertainties. Such lenses, (e.g. J1701+3722, Smith <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.12), are complimentary to SNELLS/MNELLS nearby lenses, but not identical. However, lenses within this redshift range may offer an avenue to address the differences between the SLACS and SNELLS/MNELLS conflicting samples.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443705 id=\"201443705\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the first results from the ongoing MNELLS survey, and a complementary archival sample, searching for nearby strong-lensing ETGs. We have observed 16 new targets (14 to full depth) and selected 36 comparable galaxies that were publicly available from the ESO archive at the end of February 2019. We search within each datacube for background sources that are multiply imaged or single-imaged but closely projected to the \u2018lens\u2019. We process each pipeline-reduced datacube to filter out the foreground galaxy and then search the residuals for emission lines with an automated detection process. We then manually verify the detections and find that human interpretation is key to reliable identification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the total sample, we have discovered one new galaxy-scale strong lens, J0403\u22120239, which is consistent with an MW-like IMF, \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.17 (see Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), for an assumed old stellar population. The newly acquired high S/N FORS2 spectrum of J0403\u22120239 will be used to precisely constrain the age of the stellar population and hence \u03b1. A further two new low-<em>z</em> cluster-scale lenses were discovered in which the lensing mass is dominated by DM for any plausible IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have discovered nine galaxies with closely projected but single-imaged sources (<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a06\u2009arcsec), which we use to augment the constraints on the IMF via our \u2018upper-limit lensing\u2019 technique (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Of these systems, J0202\u22125055 shows a hint of having a counter-image to its innermost source, and hence could become the fifth low-<em>z</em> lens with additional observations. If the inner image has no counter-image, the configuration implies a system that is likely consistent with an MW-like or lighter IMF. Of the other eight, only J0202\u20130107 favours a Salpeter or lighter IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combining the four confirmed low-<em>z</em> lenses with nine closely projected but single-imaged systems from this paper and two taken from Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; SNL-4 and J0728+4005), we infer the mean and intrinsic scatter of the ETG population, assuming a lognormal distribution for \u03b1. The population has \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 and a 90\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence standard deviation of \u03b1 of 0.24. This is less than the \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.09\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 and \u03c3\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.32 from only the confirmed lenses (Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). This implies that there is a higher likelihood of discovering strong lensing around massive galaxies that have higher stellar mass (i.e. more compact) due to their increased surface mass density. Therefore, although SNELLS and MNELLS lenses on average measure an \u03b1 a few\u00a0per\u2009cent larger than MW-like, the total population lies close to an MW-like IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We tested our detection flux thresholds within the MNELLS datacubes and predict that we reach a flux limit of 10<sup>\u221216.5</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. Our central sensitivity is 0.35 dex lower due to the foreground galaxy continuum. From the MUSE-wide results, we predict that one in 25 targets will be multiply imaged strong lens. So far with 14 targets we have two closely projected but single-imaged sources and no strong lenses (our reported strong-lensing galaxies are from the archival sample), which is consistent within the Poisson statistics of these predictions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper has presented the first of a series of MNELLS observations, with 21 more galaxies observed in P103 and P104 as of February 2020. Additionally, the faint object camera and spectragraph (FOCAS) on Subaru (Ozaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) offers an alternative to MUSE, and we are extending our survey technique to the Northern hemisphere. From this data set, J0202\u22125055 is a promising candidate for future follow-up observations as it appears a highly likely to be a multiply imaged strong lens for any typical IMF and has the potential for multiple source planes. With this large array of incoming data, the likelihood of discovering new low-<em>z</em> strong-lensing galaxies in the forthcoming years is high.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443712 id=\"201443712\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WC was supported by an STFC studentship (ST/N50404X/1). RJS and JRL are supported by the STFC Durham Astronomy Consolidated Grant (ST/P000541/1). This research has made use of the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED), which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This work is based on observations collected at the European Organisation for Astronomical Research in the Southern Hemisphere under various ESO programme IDs, retrieved through the ESO Science Archive Facility. This publication makes use of data products from the Two Micron All Sky Survey, which is a joint project of the University of Massachusetts and the Infrared Processing and Analysis Center/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Science Foundation. This work made use of data from observations obtained as part of the VISTA Hemisphere Survey, ESO programme, 179.A-2010 (PI: McMahon)</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443714 id=\"201443714\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">In principle the archive could be searched for strong gravitational lenses independent of specific morphologies or redshift. However, this is beyond the scope of this work, specific to the IMF of massive ETGs.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">BCGs are excluded from the targeted survey as the lensing mass is typically dominated by DM, and the galaxy has a low surface brightness and hence mass density. This leads to an <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> significantly larger than found in a typical isolated galaxy.
