13.2\u00a0</td><td>097.B-0766(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J20515691\u22125237473\u00a0</td><td>PGC065588\u00a0</td><td>14\u2009310\u00a0</td><td>41\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>097.B-0776(A),099.B-0148(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J23135863\u22124243393\u00a0</td><td>AS1101\u00a0</td><td>2700\u00a0</td><td>16\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Yes\u00a0</td><td>3.6\u00a0</td><td>094.A-0859(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J23363057+2108498\u00a0</td><td>A2626\u00a0</td><td>1800\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Potential\u00a0</td><td>3.5\u00a0</td><td>095.A-0159(A)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J23570068\u22123445331\u00a0</td><td>A4059\u00a0</td><td>10\u2009080\u00a0</td><td>33\u00a0</td><td>Yes\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>8.6, 9.8\u00a0</td><td>094.B-0592(A)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201443570\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each galaxy in the sample we select the deepest available observation, which in many cases is the MUSE-DEEP data product. The datacubes are acquired as an ESO pipeline reduced final product. The selected observations range from exposure times comparable to, or shorter than our MNELLS sample, &lt;3600 s, or much longer, &gt;10\u2009000 s and have varied seeing conditions.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443572 id=\"201443572\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 GALAXY SUBTRACTION AND EMISSION-LINE DETECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we outline our method to detect background emission-line sources. In the SNELLS survey, each datacube was visually inspected to search for background emitters. Here, we automate the process, incorporating a search algorithm as a first pass. Then we visually inspect each detection to confirm the reliability.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection process consists of two main steps: (1) the removal of the foreground lens candidate and other nearby bright continuum objects and (2) the detection and identification of emitters within the continuum-subtracted datacubes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To help isolate compact narrow emission features, we first subtract a continuum spectrum from each pixel computed using a running median with a 75\u2009\u00c5 bandwidth. The residuals from this step are next fitted with an elliptical profile computed for each wavelength channel independently, with the centre, ellipticity, and position angle fixed to match the target galaxy. When other bright sources are present in the field, their residuals are modelled similarly. This process works well except near strong spectral features in fast-rotating galaxies. After subtracting these profiles, the remaining residuals are normalized to the local standard deviation (estimated using quantiles for robustness), and smoothed with a Gaussian of 0.6\u2009arcsec full width at half-maximum (FWHM) in the spatial directions and 3.5\u2009\u00c5 FWHM in wavelength.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We developed a python-based framework for detecting emission-line features within the filtered and smoothed datacubes using routines from the <span class=\"small-caps\">scipy.ndimages.label</span> package. This package groups connected pixels above a threshold, allowing the spatially and spectrally extended peaks, due to the emission-line features, to be identified. The selection of the threshold involves a trade-off between the number of spurious detections to inspect manually, and those faint sources which may be missed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The smoothed residual datacube is separated into 40\u2009\u00c5 slices with an overlap of 5\u00c5\u2009and a labelling threshold is applied. For each labelled region, the number of pixels and the spatial extent are required to be above thresholds of 10 and 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02, respectively. Those which do not meet these criteria are not considered for further processing. These are usually artefacts from the subtraction of bright sky lines, or the lens light. If a detected source is spatially and spectrally extended, this is a strong indication of an emission line, which is then processed for identification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The candidate emitters spectrum is extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, and at \u00b1\u2009125\u2009\u00c5 around the brightest detected pixel. This range is chosen to contain [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20094959\u2009\u00c5 if the lead detection is [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20095007\u2009\u00c5, whilst avoiding H\u2009\u03b2 to simplify the emission-line fitting. (The range will also contain [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] for H\u2009\u03b1.) The extracted spectrum is then fit with a single, double and triple Gaussian, with appropriate peak ratios and separation for [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1+[N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. We perform a chi-square minimization to select the best-fitting identification and measure a redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After these detections have been carried out for each 40\u2009\u00c5 segment of the datacube, we matched detections spatially in order to combine sources with multiple emission lines at a consistent redshift, and included a step to associate the single Gaussian lines to other identified lines (generally this matches H\u2009\u03b2 to detected [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]). We do not specifically fit the asymmetric Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile, as these will be best fit with a single Gaussian with a wide FWHM, and so will be included in the sample without more complex modelling.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, the candidate lines are manually inspected and either verified as sources or rejected. Sources within a 10\u2009arcsec radius of the candidate lens centre are recorded separately. This minimizes the time per datacube on a first pass for lensed images. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show an example of the outputs which were visually inspected. Narrow-band images of the respective positions for the four strongest optical emission lines ([O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1) are displayed in the top panels. Inspecting the panels will show those detections which appear false in the spectral domain due to their lack of a clear peak, or spatial extent due to a residual (see Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">A</a> for an example of an excluded detection).</p>                        <a id=\"201443581\" scrollto-destination=\"201443581\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=LYyx3kBGUqJThrTFrQKIwqbK5SBCwC~0bvB7sOBmReOoFJKaGX5SyqMo60MXpT3iJRqqsh0qZOLcE94AoE-~~~JhCiuIxj-fwDbQQox1AjHwL5g7j8YXCntVkzAHiwfaD47YCheO18zIk9FsqytM9~cudcChDIbRCb6bERt4dzONDfvCbrfCKUlD6O7kOepZJuKASNhJ~psgX5nNb0fFSALHnSndEWGT5OMgk9xI0U0aZCNhwqnVjKOM3q25uGbAkJ1ULD9xl4uEGJYIVjKnd6zeh9GH0Zr3TNhjdPVhmtIXyoXze1vGqDPGMJS3zKSdQ-Z3S9XNp~t36KVXZBLZdw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An example emitter from an MNELLS observation. The upper panels show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009iii], and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. The panel size is 8\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, at redshift 0.3024. The emission lines extracted for the narrow-band images are indicated with the orange arrows.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443581/staa602fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443581\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=uIe1S9WECtgM-UKLZt8IRNAado3LO2LYbuLDQjLtKfpj9UR3GwCVEi1PEFxqDTBaMYTzqW6wHHj9ctcRvgb2z3nsATRv7lfdhtoaJJ1V~NO5lSh2ViJ8c2rmxLkP7BTQDhqzUJalHalmoMtE4Gj7a8lrY3Ki0c2DPHv9PhalsNJARPWJuHHW6j~2F0oXXrmmDlvTMTNmIpBoeoVb2yZgqTqftFHe4AYf~vg0l-RGb7z8LDsZTZtd6ZqPJ44ELksaYRMe2G7MmCmk~ah~-8wEonMv0jYJBo0zHnwUuZtkxZr8FfMOG2K~LAXy8lIfx~e8khVcfGCdNrQoLnadGXMtag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443581&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example emitter from an MNELLS observation. The panel size is 8\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, at redshift 0.3024. The emission lines extracted for the narrow-band images are indicated with the orange arrows.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=LYyx3kBGUqJThrTFrQKIwqbK5SBCwC~0bvB7sOBmReOoFJKaGX5SyqMo60MXpT3iJRqqsh0qZOLcE94AoE-~~~JhCiuIxj-fwDbQQox1AjHwL5g7j8YXCntVkzAHiwfaD47YCheO18zIk9FsqytM9~cudcChDIbRCb6bERt4dzONDfvCbrfCKUlD6O7kOepZJuKASNhJ~psgX5nNb0fFSALHnSndEWGT5OMgk9xI0U0aZCNhwqnVjKOM3q25uGbAkJ1ULD9xl4uEGJYIVjKnd6zeh9GH0Zr3TNhjdPVhmtIXyoXze1vGqDPGMJS3zKSdQ-Z3S9XNp~t36KVXZBLZdw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An example emitter from an MNELLS observation. The upper panels show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009iii], and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. The panel size is 8\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, at redshift 0.3024. The emission lines extracted for the narrow-band images are indicated with the orange arrows.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443581/staa602fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443581\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=uIe1S9WECtgM-UKLZt8IRNAado3LO2LYbuLDQjLtKfpj9UR3GwCVEi1PEFxqDTBaMYTzqW6wHHj9ctcRvgb2z3nsATRv7lfdhtoaJJ1V~NO5lSh2ViJ8c2rmxLkP7BTQDhqzUJalHalmoMtE4Gj7a8lrY3Ki0c2DPHv9PhalsNJARPWJuHHW6j~2F0oXXrmmDlvTMTNmIpBoeoVb2yZgqTqftFHe4AYf~vg0l-RGb7z8LDsZTZtd6ZqPJ44ELksaYRMe2G7MmCmk~ah~-8wEonMv0jYJBo0zHnwUuZtkxZr8FfMOG2K~LAXy8lIfx~e8khVcfGCdNrQoLnadGXMtag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443581&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example emitter from an MNELLS observation. The upper panels show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. The panel size is 8\u2009arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a08\u2009arcsec. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, at redshift 0.3024. The emission lines extracted for the narrow-band images are indicated with the orange arrows.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The end results of the processing described in this section is a final catalogue of visually screened emission line sources for each datacube.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443583 id=\"201443583\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 IDENTIFIED/CANDIDATE LENSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we will detail the results of the line emission search on a total of 52 galaxies. The results are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> for MNELLS and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> for the archival search.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use three main criteria for any galaxy we label as a multiply imaged lens. The first is a secure redshift for each image, from either multiple consistent emission lines or a clear [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet. The second is a configuration that has a strong resemblance to theoretical lens systems modelled with a singular isothermal sphere (SIS) or singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) parametric model. The third is any velocity offset between each image must be small (\u03bd<sub>offset</sub> &lt;100\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>), and similar emission line ratios. The presence of weaker, less commonly observed emission lines (i.e O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>, H\u03b3, H\u03b4, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], or He\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) in both spectra are also strong indicators of a common source. For a close-projected single-imaged system, only the first is relevant.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the combined sample, four galaxies show evidence for double-imaged sources, with confirmation from multiple emission lines. These are 2MASXJ04035024\u22120239275 (hereafter J0403\u22120239) an isolated elliptical, Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>, and three BCGs, from the clusters A4059, A2052, and AS555, i.e. 2MASXJ23570068\u22123445331, 2MASXJ15164448+0701180, and 2MASXJ05571255\u22123728364, respectively. Detailed discussion and analysis of these \u2018cluster-lenses\u2019 are presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">During our systematic search, we recorded separately any emitters discovered within 10\u2009arcsec of the galaxy centres. For a given lens, the region on the image-plane within which a source can form multiple images is 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>. For our sample, the typical <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> is 2\u20133\u2009arcsec (for an isothermal sphere model with velocity dispersion 260\u2013320\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>). We discovered nine galaxies with close-projected but apparently single-imaged sources within 6\u2009arcsec. These galaxies are analysed to constrain the maximum lensing mass which produces no detectable counter-image, and hence the lens galaxy IMF (\u2018upper-limit lensing\u2019; Smith, Lucey\u00a0&amp; Collier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We describe these close-projected systems in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.4</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Whilst searching for lenses in datacubes with such a large FoV, there are many cases of multiple clustered background emitters at the same redshift. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a>, we explain the criteria we use to exclude such systems.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443589 id=\"201443589\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Double-image lens J0403\u22120239</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">During the archival lens search, we discovered the strong-lens system J0403\u22120239, which is a massive (\u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0314\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>) ETG without any nearby neighbours, lying at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.06655. The pair of background emitters lie at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.195, and the system has an <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> of 1.47\u2009arcsec. This <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> probes the stellar dominated galaxy core, and in Collier et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) we reported the implications of this system on the IMF within massive ETGs. We found this galaxy to have a lightweight IMF, under the assumption of a typical old stellar population. The discovery of this lens galaxy was also independently reported by Galbany et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), who describe the potential presence of a second younger stellar population which may affect the conclusion of a lightweight IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have since acquired <em>HST</em> observations (PI: Smith) of J0403\u22120239, using Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3/UVIS). We observed with the F814W and F390W filters, for 1040 and 3900\u2009s, respectively. The imaging is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The lens has a smooth light distribution in the red (F814W), and extended lensed images with well-defined clumpy structure at shorter wavelengths (F390W). However in the F390W imaging, there are signs of irregular patchy dust obscuration running close to the lens galaxy near to the inner image (see right-hand panel, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). This adds to evidence from the MUSE datacube and wide-field imaging that suggest this galaxy has been recently perturbed.</p>                        <a id=\"201443592\" scrollto-destination=\"201443592\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=jZxHoLS8nuqpob2XxfkKndv46sCsN4Ub~vhttwBoRvYx8jDZknOSX7xCCSAunkKae-TmalNdm7G3blYVWzEVqb5HLN26OnjZNpTxT3lNwwKyzOG-bjrCX7rx1DexWqhmsALU1yQANAvZWAPQnbfcIvrryPpc5xAmYH3TCYqsUy3XY4r1564NIZT2RF3rlxpDbpCd-furw86YWkfD3-R9NBes1Mjih66SdCWil5Vs7BN7aOAxgSmwfh4h6KeCzskgqYJe1sS9Pk99KQHOB1GeGbhkzubafxMsmmOZocnRXA5cXfJBXoWf5GnbWgM8zudtMXWb6ale3m~ZI-O1Y0IckQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The recently acquired HST data for J0403\u22123055. Left: F814W HST data, showing a smooth lens light profile. The lensed images appear smooth, and a hint of a faint arc can be seen about the outer image. Middle: F390W HST data, displaying structure in the outer image. Right: A lens light subtracted image. The strongest evidence for a recent interaction is the clumpy residual which can be traced inside to the inner image, and a small plume more distant than the inner image (marked by the arrows).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443592/staa602fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443592\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=u2sgaEt6lWpfX3KlO30uKC8FCpxTpNgXFxfpzb3nIQsNqjjZrk4of~X8iIfY2hJaKIFDEzrmnLUWgvzRcXi2QZVLZ3JZGEwawna4PjfRWCOdPNYdvGlBRXvouLvoR8UQmVzn~s~HXP5FZ6I7Lxdgyqo6qVeH2evezqlNwmzaj9DDBMU4N5zKFmVb4-E9xiwhg5TLXN-vVRtNMflitlxSCnw22YJovut0w41cHg2GqYf1aWHabCxyr7upvk8CrUISq0t2JhzBSLEm0q8smufbkR1A9jwPXVjIAAM59g72hIUXlZxzpGopWMQwM9GZIFdb4b9L-lbvH3GpbsYpdMrWGA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443592&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recently acquired <em>HST</em> data for J0403\u22123055. Left: F814W <em>HST</em> data, showing a smooth lens light profile. The lensed images appear smooth, and a hint of a faint arc can be seen about the outer image. Middle: F390W <em>HST</em> data, displaying structure in the outer image. Right: A lens light subtracted image. The strongest evidence for a recent interaction is the clumpy residual which can be traced inside to the inner image, and a small plume more distant than the inner image (marked by the arrows).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=jZxHoLS8nuqpob2XxfkKndv46sCsN4Ub~vhttwBoRvYx8jDZknOSX7xCCSAunkKae-TmalNdm7G3blYVWzEVqb5HLN26OnjZNpTxT3lNwwKyzOG-bjrCX7rx1DexWqhmsALU1yQANAvZWAPQnbfcIvrryPpc5xAmYH3TCYqsUy3XY4r1564NIZT2RF3rlxpDbpCd-furw86YWkfD3-R9NBes1Mjih66SdCWil5Vs7BN7aOAxgSmwfh4h6KeCzskgqYJe1sS9Pk99KQHOB1GeGbhkzubafxMsmmOZocnRXA5cXfJBXoWf5GnbWgM8zudtMXWb6ale3m~ZI-O1Y0IckQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The recently acquired HST data for J0403\u22123055. Left: F814W HST data, showing a smooth lens light profile. The lensed images appear smooth, and a hint of a faint arc can be seen about the outer image. Middle: F390W HST data, displaying structure in the outer image. Right: A lens light subtracted image. The strongest evidence for a recent interaction is the clumpy residual which can be traced inside to the inner image, and a small plume more distant than the inner image (marked by the arrows).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443592/staa602fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443592\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=u2sgaEt6lWpfX3KlO30uKC8FCpxTpNgXFxfpzb3nIQsNqjjZrk4of~X8iIfY2hJaKIFDEzrmnLUWgvzRcXi2QZVLZ3JZGEwawna4PjfRWCOdPNYdvGlBRXvouLvoR8UQmVzn~s~HXP5FZ6I7Lxdgyqo6qVeH2evezqlNwmzaj9DDBMU4N5zKFmVb4-E9xiwhg5TLXN-vVRtNMflitlxSCnw22YJovut0w41cHg2GqYf1aWHabCxyr7upvk8CrUISq0t2JhzBSLEm0q8smufbkR1A9jwPXVjIAAM59g72hIUXlZxzpGopWMQwM9GZIFdb4b9L-lbvH3GpbsYpdMrWGA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443592&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recently acquired <em>HST</em> data for J0403\u22123055. Left: F814W <em>HST</em> data, showing a smooth lens light profile. The lensed images appear smooth, and a hint of a faint arc can be seen about the outer image. Middle: F390W <em>HST</em> data, displaying structure in the outer image. Right: A lens light subtracted image. The strongest evidence for a recent interaction is the clumpy residual which can be traced inside to the inner image, and a small plume more distant than the inner image (marked by the arrows).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We perform lens analysis with <span class=\"small-caps\">pyautolens</span> (Nightingale, Dye\u00a0&amp; Massey <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) using the F390W <em>HST</em> images to exploit the lensed image structure. Modelling the source with either a S\u00e9rsic model, or a full pixelized inversion, we find a compact source as a best-fitting solution to the lens plane image positions and shape. Therefore, the only change in constraints relative to the earlier analysis is that the peak pixel <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> is 1.49\u2009arcsec, which is 0.5\u00a0per\u2009cent larger than the same measurement in the MUSE data. This changes our mass-measurement by less than 2\u00a0per\u2009cent (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.17). Hence our previous conclusions are unchanged.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the new <em>HST</em> imaging, we observed J0403\u22120239 with ESO/VLT FORS2. The wavelength coverage of the new data (3660\u20135110\u2009\u00c5) is blueward of MUSE (4750\u20139350\u2009\u00c5), and hence contains the higher order Balmer series, and the Ca\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> doublet. These absorption features are key to precisely constraining the age of a stellar population. With the FORS2 data we can test our assumption that J0403\u22120239 has a single, old stellar population against the old population \u2018frosted\u2019 with a considerably more recent starburst which is measured from the MUSE data with STARLIGHT (Galbany et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We extract a spectrum within an aperture matched to the <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>, covering the wavelength range 3900\u20134800\u2009\u00c5 to include the high-order Balmer series, see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. As a simple comparison, we overlay the FORS2 spectrum with two different age SSPs from the MILES models (Vazdekis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), assuming a bimodal IMF with a slope of \u22121.30. We select models which are \u03b1-enhanced, and metal-rich with ages of 2.75\u2009Gyr (Galbany et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, measured a 2.6\u2009Gyr luminosity-weighted population), and 12\u2009Gyr (an old population was assumed by Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) which are redshifted to 0.066, and smoothed to \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0314\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p>                        <a id=\"201443596\" scrollto-destination=\"201443596\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=J1vo55SV1kJ2P5UsrdDJ3LlELL9e7qfbGY7el3r6QXzbichVIvgYxMS60wt1YEol1RwNWPiKbS~9WSSOcyNUnLRHMfOR-2JhpMf2R6tP2im9mRADzjo8yNyQEmhYOi19STj1Mfdgs~IkE0Brq~XlRGi2yM3gXfGaWmUOcL5Inq6n8SItxum4bDn2jdYMVcR-xh4WClKSW-~Gqy3K4qk7-Ub5sHh9tEwXd0jY9Jqg9JTKS1rJSpSZmY9AcFBEk-fGEaIp-8BvjCNt0uDXjvYSYXgPmFBqAb-mn~Az~-M7TJmkvga6qpUEDk3U7hXLcovCF5ajtasMCd87EQdlKZVLZA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The recently acquired ESO/VLT FORS2 data for J0403\u22123055 extracted within REin an displayed in grey. The data are not flux calibrated, and hence we match the continuum shape to an old stellar population. We compare the data with two differently aged SSPs from the MILES library (Vazdekis et\u00a0al. 2010). The upper is an old, 12\u2009Gyr population, which is \u03b1-enhanced and metal-rich. The lower is a 2.75\u2009Gyr population as suggested by Galbany et\u00a0al. (2018). We label the H\u2009\u03b4 and H\u2009\u03b3 absorption features, which appear better matched by the older population.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443596/staa602fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443596\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=Toc15FhuVMHkRtlkDvffrDirisBizocS~DwaAE3lWG2R2HYS2hy-2IjOIaIIVpwZ~Ok~9zrYJV4bPBvwfy5dncVG9KimfeBXN9Oh6bJrMX-2m-wK-4TBcnCeNcYv6FEAlVTio3XKvzBocAWAwnwMEFp42-RZ8XD3lTTNI3K8wVHUdG~qyQDRGinFa~izjk67wOMkY2f~iNeyKMuMvf7swRNmkn6zRttoYJyncQ~bt-ewpGsto4tKXrMPJ2tdhBvwTmmd3BwDwrLxb-6fhb3PBwxn9sRftCOGcwiWEdTohMntD-3z79wNAqXPb~yTGlfHB7kbIbHnOhAruGBgI~jlDQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443596&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recently acquired ESO/VLT FORS2 data for J0403\u22123055 extracted within <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> an displayed in grey. The data are not flux calibrated, and hence we match the continuum shape to an old stellar population. We compare the data with two differently aged SSPs from the MILES library (Vazdekis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The upper is an old, 12\u2009Gyr population, which is \u03b1-enhanced and metal-rich. The lower is a 2.75\u2009Gyr population as suggested by Galbany et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We label the H\u2009\u03b4 and H\u2009\u03b3 absorption features, which appear better matched by the older population.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=J1vo55SV1kJ2P5UsrdDJ3LlELL9e7qfbGY7el3r6QXzbichVIvgYxMS60wt1YEol1RwNWPiKbS~9WSSOcyNUnLRHMfOR-2JhpMf2R6tP2im9mRADzjo8yNyQEmhYOi19STj1Mfdgs~IkE0Brq~XlRGi2yM3gXfGaWmUOcL5Inq6n8SItxum4bDn2jdYMVcR-xh4WClKSW-~Gqy3K4qk7-Ub5sHh9tEwXd0jY9Jqg9JTKS1rJSpSZmY9AcFBEk-fGEaIp-8BvjCNt0uDXjvYSYXgPmFBqAb-mn~Az~-M7TJmkvga6qpUEDk3U7hXLcovCF5ajtasMCd87EQdlKZVLZA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The recently acquired ESO/VLT FORS2 data for J0403\u22123055 extracted within REin an displayed in grey. The data are not flux calibrated, and hence we match the continuum shape to an old stellar population. We compare the data with two differently aged SSPs from the MILES library (Vazdekis et\u00a0al. 2010). The upper is an old, 12\u2009Gyr population, which is \u03b1-enhanced and metal-rich. The lower is a 2.75\u2009Gyr population as suggested by Galbany et\u00a0al. (2018). We label the H\u2009\u03b4 and H\u2009\u03b3 absorption features, which appear better matched by the older population.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443596/staa602fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443596\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=Toc15FhuVMHkRtlkDvffrDirisBizocS~DwaAE3lWG2R2HYS2hy-2IjOIaIIVpwZ~Ok~9zrYJV4bPBvwfy5dncVG9KimfeBXN9Oh6bJrMX-2m-wK-4TBcnCeNcYv6FEAlVTio3XKvzBocAWAwnwMEFp42-RZ8XD3lTTNI3K8wVHUdG~qyQDRGinFa~izjk67wOMkY2f~iNeyKMuMvf7swRNmkn6zRttoYJyncQ~bt-ewpGsto4tKXrMPJ2tdhBvwTmmd3BwDwrLxb-6fhb3PBwxn9sRftCOGcwiWEdTohMntD-3z79wNAqXPb~yTGlfHB7kbIbHnOhAruGBgI~jlDQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443596&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recently acquired ESO/VLT FORS2 data for J0403\u22123055 extracted within <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> an displayed in grey. The data are not flux calibrated, and hence we match the continuum shape to an old stellar population. We compare the data with two differently aged SSPs from the MILES library (Vazdekis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The upper is an old, 12\u2009Gyr population, which is \u03b1-enhanced and metal-rich. The lower is a 2.75\u2009Gyr population as suggested by Galbany et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We label the H\u2009\u03b4 and H\u2009\u03b3 absorption features, which appear better matched by the older population.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The FORS2 spectrum does not exhibit the strong H\u03b3 and H\u03b4 absorption expected from a &lt;3\u2009Gyr stellar population, nor the strong high-order Balmer absorption characteristic of composite populations with &lt;1\u2009Gyr components. Despite the evidence for a recent interaction or accretion event in J0403\u22120239, the FORS2 spectrum supports the assumption in Collier et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) of an old stellar population inside the <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>. A more rigorous analysis will be presented elsewhere.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443598 id=\"201443598\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Multiply imaged cluster lenses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to J0403\u22120239, we discover multiply imaged sources behind two cluster BCGs (2MASXJ23570068\u22123445331 and 2MASXJ15164448+0701180). These detections are shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. We also report a third potential lens, 2MASXJ05571255\u22123728364, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. These are each among the lowest redshift clusters known to have multiply imaged sources.</p>                        <a id=\"201443600\" scrollto-destination=\"201443600\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=BEbYY4huEdCh2n-cJ~ooWJWLkY6Gf9TDQBvI4cTVo7-KbLJQXxjPEWjL0T2ptAeoQsJHTuAS5~qj-5jPPvotbGR7eObsuVJXRK58kWxIdWVZLWBVPgUsaaKC6TsIZP9MEppo0VsedONT32UwISYGRSz~P4q9wGQYNLhLngFmF83BREuCXXl04XODuOfLC-ryFOQ55FSEpcesHVzEUrKQxB27TwF0W1KEbYmtmiERhSXSZ2FRJi-xePwl6EIsTnv~Z8oWZQiPPD6bUkWvMNPvup5ya4btB0XPJHZ7YSqQCp1yoigvSszuEjRdslZj1to8rhVwW7cZAfcOB6faTeHQxQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data for the BCG J2357\u22123445 and the extracted spectra of the multiply imaged background emitter. (a) The MUSE data, collapsed over the full wavelength range, for J2357\u22123445. Contours at the peak [O\u2009iii] emission for the background emitters are displayed in red. Panel (b)\u2013(d) show the emission from the two images with their negligible velocity offset in [O\u2009ii], [Ne\u2009iii], and [O\u2009iii], respectively, which confirm the single source of origin.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443600/staa602fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443600\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=gZsOTKstQ24iEop9IOgwDI9B2xEcL-AJD~Wbz61Lu~HvHCzCYc0wY~1EnIMPgKYQyHEldqnl3Ap1P9ruHKRV-jersRxqMvAlsvdfam4MfoWbwjAKx0toQFAz8OWSEiW5w1ph3WyULUA-rqbxsuZCYRrBfsmBlGRyZ9oSL3rxWbYZ0Z8rCXD3voX~gDj8jC9~sqtQnkfZiIty3XeDk1wxtt4~N1ksxvuysfqcZRG7wRMsblF-smSjJJHR80n~qg1Hcg8fJZgYLC8b-~PNXT-T1O9Ul2Pg-5ktTGra80O3s4Dfq3z04YQ-Kcpb5H4gGZXACylGXcnfbzydC9E0BbhfsA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443600&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data for the BCG J2357\u22123445 and the extracted spectra of the multiply imaged background emitter. (a) The MUSE data for J1516+0701 collapsed over the full wavelength range, with red contours denoting the position of the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u20091.377 background emitters. (b) The [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission from images A and B overlaid. There is very little velocity offset; however, A only hints at a complete doublet structure. The structure in image A cannot be ruled out in image B.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=MiRdKYQDKXrgJ9Le~MkdEDjLP-QcSKlcADrqdaKypOt7nIL~Z9gMoqhyS57WacsgZbTnPpifNU4BINvCLEIKM-1gmI0-Zz6DnH0nxl38dPfrdC9h4SeLQJ0TvYcJK6tJWvD2wQ2o-ftUmF79HenZQW-bKo6S7h4ACI2JtEDcuZhEyb7WRgvSoOzQmwckGbHXWBdC7U45SmwtUQcZUkFpxPw4LA9uXoHDhsDSnVE7tBUcS6fsduzovKBX4yg1bKVOUwwx1hvsaHrUgrqcQ5gK2fUPdOanCOP8XNiTBxFiccitNVPg2t1GCl-sZLjrWFr~QBr8PPIduw939qDrmDzLAA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data for the BCG J1516+0701 and the extracted background emitter spectra. (a) The MUSE data for J1516+0701 collapsed over the full wavelength range, with red contours denoting the position of the z\u00a0=\u20091.377 background emitters. (b) The [O\u2009ii] emission from images A and B overlaid. There is very little velocity offset; however, A only hints at a complete doublet structure. The structure in image A cannot be ruled out in image B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443601/staa602fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443601\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=2pc605QWWaz6-4SRfbfSzqU4N0f7pW14i28DtwICYffoSQg43w5o4mYAhzKhPnGXwSaAj2Kk2S3i4a2~NBFA2cDLny1xg-ZSrWePVed74q3K~Ddc0ZbcmFRKliVPMV7mDtYQrOK52oU4QelPYSWygXWXXFlABhkXofPoXNdS1oPG4cFzUD3hj20-fkqvhxKKNg0y6bZIOpbLmQidonYNK6dy9NGhVedsFhj7TGZ8L05K0E3w62KaXNhhk0LnT3QaUH-j5UloxtVecU5l4eF-Q6giXdI~f9v23FK5go1hVV2EdN-QUUp3Tp1D83Hlx99Kb3ruk6Dyisq1ipJikHV~SA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443601&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data for the BCG J1516+0701 and the extracted background emitter spectra. (a) The MUSE data for J1516+0701 collapsed over the full wavelength range, with red contours denoting the position of the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u20091.377 background emitters. (b) The [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission from images A and B overlaid. There is very little velocity offset; however, A only hints at a complete doublet structure. The structure in image A cannot be ruled out in image B.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"201443602\" scrollto-destination=\"201443602\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=jqUlDT9F42t1G67GDnPRRUELFIgMJjv~Xe-72QOAm~ZKSvkZ~HCT5T0hEMxdysJeyNu1xtLsFwEMWZEkl5Uw-Bku4NX4fNXKPesJ-J~May8t1ll6qD9m~pJ-lfyD6OZ0-q-3~6UhFrozslt-HucPp-3uU2VV483bX-9XXsnlgYFtbRBC1BZdF7qlTWuJdrH7W1TCtJiiK~lD3cwKNrNVgibomgAc7brx4YG4HBsXga5J4Eok6nuK4T2mxq~2vinoT3v2GJUPIkhkSL6jH4OjUrwsjoUqRIovUDD4Y2~gv0HSH9q7tPX3iI3231RAe45~-b~E8V1Ceey1ydIAwlfwTA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data for the BCG J0557\u22123728, and the extracted background emitter spectra. (a) The MUSE data for J0557\u22123728 collapsed over the full wavelength range which shows the close, small companion galaxy. Overlaid on top are the contours of the [O\u2009ii] emission for the candidate lensed images. Panels (b)\u2013(d) show the strongest emission lines from the three clumps labelled in panel (a).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443602/staa602fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443602\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=RP0vI7OSOoXRoGKVFWzRDATnq7hFkRqzWCU-IaIG5VYePFTM69whU4oH736neKRqzefdFfDHdrnzufccV7Tn5AgiKK7OlYWKP~ZsDvkvmJc0T-3-1g7SQTSVoODm-9eIbe2SV6fZxS4CkcX3nGCn-P1jlqdobjfgu3nzzQpfs4rris0BbMc2pliuWOj2fAzGep5K9rJbkLO6nXSFFNH8Yzw22jA~~nCLyKRzzxVqziPE9tdEivVraaxXSlkInu~xDWy8YoBPVkZdhBGIqdcnhnqFtLm10Ty-wc8P4Z8KiNIn3wq3q2Tcq6dx4Byqo~txEt6vKP04MAa62VrAWRD6Sw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443602&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data for the BCG J0557\u22123728, and the extracted background emitter spectra. (a) The MUSE data for J0557\u22123728 collapsed over the full wavelength range which shows the close, small companion galaxy. Overlaid on top are the contours of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission for the candidate lensed images. Panels (b)\u2013(d) show the strongest emission lines from the three clumps labelled in panel (a).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=jqUlDT9F42t1G67GDnPRRUELFIgMJjv~Xe-72QOAm~ZKSvkZ~HCT5T0hEMxdysJeyNu1xtLsFwEMWZEkl5Uw-Bku4NX4fNXKPesJ-J~May8t1ll6qD9m~pJ-lfyD6OZ0-q-3~6UhFrozslt-HucPp-3uU2VV483bX-9XXsnlgYFtbRBC1BZdF7qlTWuJdrH7W1TCtJiiK~lD3cwKNrNVgibomgAc7brx4YG4HBsXga5J4Eok6nuK4T2mxq~2vinoT3v2GJUPIkhkSL6jH4OjUrwsjoUqRIovUDD4Y2~gv0HSH9q7tPX3iI3231RAe45~-b~E8V1Ceey1ydIAwlfwTA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data for the BCG J0557\u22123728, and the extracted background emitter spectra. (a) The MUSE data for J0557\u22123728 collapsed over the full wavelength range which shows the close, small companion galaxy. Overlaid on top are the contours of the [O\u2009ii] emission for the candidate lensed images. Panels (b)\u2013(d) show the strongest emission lines from the three clumps labelled in panel (a).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443602/staa602fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443602\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=RP0vI7OSOoXRoGKVFWzRDATnq7hFkRqzWCU-IaIG5VYePFTM69whU4oH736neKRqzefdFfDHdrnzufccV7Tn5AgiKK7OlYWKP~ZsDvkvmJc0T-3-1g7SQTSVoODm-9eIbe2SV6fZxS4CkcX3nGCn-P1jlqdobjfgu3nzzQpfs4rris0BbMc2pliuWOj2fAzGep5K9rJbkLO6nXSFFNH8Yzw22jA~~nCLyKRzzxVqziPE9tdEivVraaxXSlkInu~xDWy8YoBPVkZdhBGIqdcnhnqFtLm10Ty-wc8P4Z8KiNIn3wq3q2Tcq6dx4Byqo~txEt6vKP04MAa62VrAWRD6Sw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443602&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data for the BCG J0557\u22123728, and the extracted background emitter spectra. (a) The MUSE data for J0557\u22123728 collapsed over the full wavelength range which shows the close, small companion galaxy. Overlaid on top are the contours of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission for the candidate lensed images. Panels (b)\u2013(d) show the strongest emission lines from the three clumps labelled in panel (a).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443603 id=\"201443603\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-1>4.2.1 2MASX J23570068\u22123445331</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The first candidate lens, J2357\u22123445, lies at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.0491 and is the cluster BCG of A4059. This cluster lies at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.0487, with a size of <em>R</em><sub>500</sub>\u2009\u2243\u20090.96\u2009Mpc and a mass <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>\u2009\u2243\u20092.67\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> taken from the \u2018meta-catalogue of X-ray detected clusters of galaxies\u2019 (MCXC; Piffaretti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). This cluster has been subject to multiwaveband observations, which could provide additional information to describe this lensing system. In <em>HST</em>/WFPC2 F814W imaging (Choi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), the presence of a dust lane is clear. Furthermore, large plumes of filamentary nebular emission at the cluster redshift (McDonald et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) is present in the MUSE data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We detect two background emitters in the MUSE datacube separated by 17.15\u2009arcsec which are at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.512 (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5a</a>). In the <em>HST</em> data, there is a very faint source coincident with image A, though it cannot be unambiguously determined as related. Though the separation is large, the spectra are similar, with consistent line ratios of [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5(b)</a>\u2013(d). A strong suggestion of these sharing a common source, and not being two different background galaxies, is the presence of weak [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] \u03bb3869 and He\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> \u03bb3888 lines, which are present in both spectra with similar line ratios. Neither of these lines is commonly observed in galaxy spectra, hence these images are likely to originate from a single background source. Image A appears slightly extended, which cannot be ruled out to be present in image B. Due to the small velocity offsets, and rare emission lines, this system is labelled a lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The very large angular separation means J2357\u22123445 is a weaker tool for investigating the IMF, as additional information is required to disentangle the dark and stellar matter once the lensing mass is estimated. Indeed, in such an environment, it is expected the cluster DM will dominate the lensing mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fitting an SIE profile to images A and B measures a lensing mass within the half image-separation of 1.79\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This is over six times larger than expected from the stellar mass alone, for an MW-like IMF, which indicates that DM is likely dominating the lensing mass. A more detailed discussion is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443608 id=\"201443608\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-2>4.2.2 2MASXJ15164448+0701180</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J1516+0701 is a massive elliptical galaxy, at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u20090.0345. It is the BCG of A2052 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.0355), which has an X-ray measured <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>, and <em>R</em><sub>500</sub>, of 2.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> and 0.95 Mpc (Piffaretti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). There is some extended emission in the datacube, indicating that this is an active galaxy and complicating the detection of background objects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The pairs of emitters lie west-east in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6(a)</a>, and are separated by 19.4\u2009arcsec. The closest image, A, is located 7.4\u2009arcsec west, and B is 13.2\u2009arcsec east from J1516+0701, and they are separated by &lt;50\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> in velocity space. The emitters were detected from the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.376, see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6(b)</a>. There are no other spectral lines in the MUSE wavelength coverage. Both images appear to share the same structure, with two distinct clumps in A, and potentially the same in B. There are archival <em>HST</em> observations (WFPC2 F814W, 6500s; PI:Geisler) however we cannot detect any obvious counterparts to the MUSE detections. Due to the similar extended structure and clear doublet in image B, we label this a strong-lensing system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This system is similar to J2357\u22123445, being located in a cluster environment; however, the extended emission maybe indicates the presence of star formation or an active galactic nuclei. This makes the system even more complex for investigating the IMF as selecting a reference mass-to-light ratio (\u03a5<sub>ref</sub>) is more uncertain.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From SIE parametrized lens-modelling, the mass within half the image separation is 1.65\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This is seven times larger than expected from a stellar population alone from an MW-like IMF. Therefore the lensing mass for the galaxy probably has a significant contribution from DM. A more detailed discussion is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443613 id=\"201443613\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-3>4.2.3 2MASXJ05571255\u22123728364</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The final and least secure cluster candidate is J0557\u22123728, the BCG of AS555, which lies at redshift 0.0448. The cluster has a redshift, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.0440, with an X-ray measured <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> and <em>R</em><sub>500</sub> of 0.97\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> and 0.69\u2009Mpc (Piffaretti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). There is a significantly smaller companion galaxy separated by \u223c3.2\u2009arcsec, but no similarly sized nearby galaxies within 2 arcmin. The emitters were discovered via strong [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission, at redshift 0.87. However, the candidate lensed images do not follow a classic lensing configuration, A is located 20.7\u2009arcsec south-south-east, with C only 3\u2009arcsec further, and B is located 16.2\u2009arcsec north, meaning that the images do not intersect the lens galaxy. There is a small velocity offset of 80\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> between A and C, and between B and C. We tentatively label this system as a lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This system is significantly more complex than the previous two cluster lenses, and the exposure time is relatively short (2700 s) which limits the detection of faint sources. The surrounding environment does not appear to suggest that a large external shear is the cause of the non-standard configuration. One potential explanation could be that J0557\u22123728 is offset from the centre of the AS555 cluster DM. An alternative explanation originates from the line strength ratios between the different images, Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7(b)</a>\u2013(d). Common lines (i.e. H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]) are stronger, and weaker in varying ratios between the three images. This may be due to differential magnification of components of a single source. This may be explained by the source is crossing a caustic line, and the existence of image C potentially adds evidence for this explanation, as it may be part of image A. Due to the complex nature of this system, and few constraints, we do not attempt to model this system for the purpose of constraining the IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Further data, such as deeper MUSE observations, could help to confirm the lensing configuration, ruling out or discovering additional faint counter-images which could be used to constrain this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443617 id=\"201443617\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Multiple close emitters</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Within any search for multiply imaged lensing systems, there will be cases for which the observations do not provide conclusive evidence. Often the distinguishing features between a lensing and non-lensing interpretation require significant case-by-case analysis. As summarized in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, the three main criteria are the redshift quality, the lensing configuration, and the velocity offset between images. To illustrate the decision process we show two examples of rejected systems in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">B</a> along with an explanation of the evidence which led to them being rejected. The first case is rejected due to a significant velocity offset, and varying lines ratios. The second is excluded as there is no apparent counter-image, and the sources are located outside of the expected multiple-imaging regime.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443619 id=\"201443619\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Singly imaged candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Although multiply image systems provide the strongest constraints, there is also information in estimating upper limits for <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> of a lensing system in which only a single closely projected emitter is detected (e.g. Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Accounting consistently for such systems can help mitigate lensing selection bias. Here, we follow the Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) methodology, but with a larger and more uniform sample. We select singly imaged, but closely projected \u2018lenses\u2019 as those galaxies with an emitter within 6\u2009arcsec of the galaxy centre, shown in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Within our data set we discovered nine such candidates. Each detection is visually inspected in the spatial and spectral domain to confirm the emission lines. Each of the nine (six and three from the archival and targeted searches respectively) candidates is displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, and are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. These are the best candidates for single lensing analysis. We exclude 2MASXJ23363057+2108498 and 2MASXJ13242275\u22123142239 which each have sources within 6\u2009arcsec in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. In each of these cases the source only has a single line detected which we do not find compelling (due to the lack of clear [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] or Ly\u03b1 structure), and therefore do not have a confidently identified redshift.</p>                        <a id=\"201443621\" scrollto-destination=\"201443621\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=ZTZ-YJUVRzijXe4V~fJIHC3uiIewaLCi38tlatEbJhTWa0aRBJvY2mcKJ7aAG2Z~F2Bz0TGGLVlTzfJ5v99Ldt~k~9gcadzJYQBXmvUDf-6gSGNqz5dIm40vIXBiEZ1b5tH5tZFGmBouvALJVDedG2j8AzJzoJLHVbg1fVSlpS2cX1lmlambtjS-NDgwgUJWGWNb2sC5Oe3CTiKdc7nd7DfIyS-tLr7buS-bxO1xlRro5PJBrS0JDBsWjW-wkN33ii6VEuhNbybbaTCqaEcZMJKT4zKaXynCiNrFJVEeSdEKschNUyLG41sseUmWB~lZgdMcL4DaMX8cj8XJ9oys5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The single-imaged systems as described in Section\u00a04.4. Each frame consists of the collapsed MUSE datacube across the full spectral range, overlaid with an orange contour of the brightest peak of emission for the single-imaged closely projected background emitter. All panels have the same scale, and are 12 arcmin\u00a0\u00d7\u00a012 arcmin. Underneath each MUSE frame is the spectrum extracted at peak of the emission, and only with the brightest peak/doublet shown. In the majority of cases this is the [O\u2009iii] doublet.
