The detection process follows that used for the targeted observations.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=sJ9Gicr8B~I10ZHyULqPeNQk2p0YGBNWRUuHdRENaDjt29guGNWd3QqMGv5PvuDr08MkMsQgdQFChBvgIavePKRyo2NiNEB5k0pV~wqmjoDiaGTQ5csTntRlZhvLAOHppnfJzKYtHZXnX7dlUOxBuTnlaApIUXQk-e~KMbNnqSqEG~EqdkOjSFl7BCAnaHO5~9zr3D1Z5ZxfqpgoYjTyTBA0BvaqFmOmqBzNkSGxp~1RrL7eC619xQJV739xHLpfyCYhLg8ctLdva77zt4xvrl8FFNM4rTO0OXDjjgaQsGICQSL90ng2KQ9dJdLhXNmK8uCSG8LQDtzUJRmjSoEWZg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Recovery fraction detected/injected, from the insertion and detection of fake point sources for four different wavelengths within a single MUSE datacube. The detection process follows that used for the targeted observations.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443691/staa602fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443691\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=x7YjlYGtfvypm4BU9jH0aU6fbI95C1Gjj3Ne8N7kP8X7f6IB5w2Pgp7W2tAzmo~SAXIvHpR8AjkU4BSLlEUkt7iUWBhTwdvdIlmInmwwS6kfQ8rAuWxCuyKHF3D9OguM8UTRa5opkUtk3bQlWIV0YdyVeY5hEieNfZKbUiSi-LkvDz-YoyfFu~xNpOwQp3i~qx7tSuIswQFeyy2HtrdGqqQh-7V62COIS3VDJ0x2fOoH6E8L9JJzqnxvgDNDG1TsHjXwGuo~ck8JJvthZnyJceX74v9J26nRd-XwI2or9kqjVThKqC~C23B031-oZwZ4ZfxESOXN2TNldRdYhlLx9w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443691&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recovery fraction detected/injected, from the insertion and detection of fake point sources for four different wavelengths within a single MUSE datacube. The detection process follows that used for the targeted observations.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For comparison to these results, we have performed the same fake source injection into a MUSE-Wide datacube. We reach a threshold \u223c0.5 dex fainter (at 7100\u2009\u00c5) with this data. The difference originates from the sky background due to their observations taking place in dark time. After the ETG is filtered, the MNELLS background is on average three times higher, with the most significant difference seen at 5000\u2009\u00c5 (due to the high FLI), and the weakest at 7242.5\u2009\u00c5 where the noise is instead dominated by a bright sky line.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our search is designed to target sources which are close to the centre of a foreground galaxy. Hence we incur a much larger contribution to the noise than just the sky background at small lens-source angular separation. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> shows the detection limit for the 7100\u2009\u00c5 channel as a function of radius. Within 6\u2009arcsec of the galaxy centre (\u223c2\u2009<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>), the flux threshold is typically 0.35 dex brighter than the full FoV. Beyond a radius of 10\u2009arcsec the sensitivity shows no strong radial dependence.</p>                        <a id=\"201443694\" scrollto-destination=\"201443694\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=gDfHcJI13Ke4-Kar0JkVSjm2tn-nGbTS7v1VWxxems9U92eupTdJPhErLgQdQjWevSWzeIra2y0GxX1P51A1~hTkXZHbbLNuaA763BqJanJ-j1PVpckNdz~v1bwAFn3qwABIANDAwtzyc8ZW7V6PxKJAQcgzqj3uxoN-Wo9AUbzefb2WZdCyIo5m70KDsKkqKYjH2GqNIiXLNmD5RJwP9oc2ntVjn4XkiqUAgeu1Ytmn1iRK~EwCFymUok2Qjj-Ks4lBZrLmoHyWSjFohfpt5OhLgHY7nDpgqXQqevTAibCvZgBWY8nLaWaiM8dRvvf2t9Q56Aw3nvJN6YlDgfnymQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a012 (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2REin is marked with a dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443694/staa602fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443694\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=VQVu6xYFom9-j3BB94Msvgww1a9gS99gm~lIQv~mMNlQpNmSONrxcbYjfW-rXkTV8c3F4MWakJTfLsqYA6tzAO23poaqjNwB7bmGX7zhSHLVhgqKX0NNXncbR9JyaB4QO-LBEE1tRS99Ssy1bhDN65WKKKc8Oko20cS8h3g32lMTVEsj4shAmdxze6Ft7iztrc76hOVeOasm~qZUbR9-pyf055iWlOR5y8aQvW8bvMuDqNuwTR6ZLel5hptOnQwH46m2EEBKCBKHTaBtL4QDb7zVRvrN3lxVO6J8PMwxA5tARxE25~gtnUFSgr8HyVtBar1rFUGPNIEsjprvhoDfSQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443694&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> is marked with a dashed line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=gDfHcJI13Ke4-Kar0JkVSjm2tn-nGbTS7v1VWxxems9U92eupTdJPhErLgQdQjWevSWzeIra2y0GxX1P51A1~hTkXZHbbLNuaA763BqJanJ-j1PVpckNdz~v1bwAFn3qwABIANDAwtzyc8ZW7V6PxKJAQcgzqj3uxoN-Wo9AUbzefb2WZdCyIo5m70KDsKkqKYjH2GqNIiXLNmD5RJwP9oc2ntVjn4XkiqUAgeu1Ytmn1iRK~EwCFymUok2Qjj-Ks4lBZrLmoHyWSjFohfpt5OhLgHY7nDpgqXQqevTAibCvZgBWY8nLaWaiM8dRvvf2t9Q56Aw3nvJN6YlDgfnymQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a012 (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2REin is marked with a dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443694/staa602fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443694\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=VQVu6xYFom9-j3BB94Msvgww1a9gS99gm~lIQv~mMNlQpNmSONrxcbYjfW-rXkTV8c3F4MWakJTfLsqYA6tzAO23poaqjNwB7bmGX7zhSHLVhgqKX0NNXncbR9JyaB4QO-LBEE1tRS99Ssy1bhDN65WKKKc8Oko20cS8h3g32lMTVEsj4shAmdxze6Ft7iztrc76hOVeOasm~qZUbR9-pyf055iWlOR5y8aQvW8bvMuDqNuwTR6ZLel5hptOnQwH46m2EEBKCBKHTaBtL4QDb7zVRvrN3lxVO6J8PMwxA5tARxE25~gtnUFSgr8HyVtBar1rFUGPNIEsjprvhoDfSQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443694&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection threshold radially binned for fake sources injected into a real datacube. This is for only the \u2018best\u2019 wavelength channel taken from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> (7100\u00c5). We show the detection limit within each bin for changing recovery fraction. There is a large drop in the threshold for the centremost radii due to the subtraction of the foreground candidate \u2018lens\u2019. The typical predicted 2<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> is marked with a dashed line.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443695 id=\"201443695\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Number density of background emitters</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this subsection we consider the number density of background emitters actually detected within our targeted observations. We also compare to the MUSE-Wide for our measured flux threshold. As described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>, the MNELLS observations are shallow exposures taken in poor seeing conditions. In our calculations, we only include the 14 fields that have the full exposure time; in total these fields have 164 detected emitters. The average full depth area within a combined datacube is 0.92 square arcmin, therefore the median number density of emitters within our full depth observations is 12.7 per square arcmin; the field-to-field standard deviation is 5.5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The full depth MUSE-wide survey reaches a number density of 37.4 emitters per square arcmin. In comparison with MNELLS, each observation is 20\u00a0per\u2009cent longer (a 1\u2009hr exposure), in conditions with a lower sky background (observed in dark/grey time instead of grey/bright). So, using their figure 13, and with our cut off at a depth of 10<sup>\u221216.1</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup> (for 90\u00a0per\u2009cent to be detected), we would predict 6.3 emitters per square arcmin. The number density from our MUSE data (12.7 arcmin<sup>\u22122</sup>) is actually twice this. The detection threshold which aligns these two values is a flux limit of 10<sup>\u221216.5</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. From Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, this suggests we should adopt a 60\u00a0per\u2009cent detection limit to align our numbers with the MUSE-Wide.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the central 6\u2009arcsec where the detection threshold for 60\u00a0per\u2009cent recovery (to match the achieved number density of emitters) is 10<sup>\u221216.15</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, the MUSE-wide predicted number count is 6.3 arcmin<sup>\u22122</sup> (an 80\u00a0per\u2009cent decrease). For the average targeted galaxy, the strong lensing regime encompasses 23 square arcsec (\u03c0<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub><sup>2</sup>; <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.9\u2009arcsec). The resulting probability for a lens galaxy having a detectable multiply imaged source is 0.04. So we expect one in 25 observed galaxies will exhibit a multiply imaged background source. Note that the counter-images may be fainter than the detection threshold.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443699 id=\"201443699\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 Considerations for future MNELLS-like surveys</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The MNELLS project observational constraints (e.g. no moon constraints) were selected to maximize the number of executed observations by taking advantage of underused observatory conditions, under the assumption that the ETG will dominate the background. We predict the number of lenses to be one in every 25 full depth observations, and in calculating this we uncovered a few key contributions affecting our detection limits which need to be considered for future targeted surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The background noise from the lunar continuum, and sky brightness has clearly affected our detection limits. The variable observing conditions (specifically the FLI and sky background) may provide a simple explanation for the origin of the large field-to-field scatter in the number of detected emitters, independent of the lens light. In addition the subtraction of the ETG also negatively impacts the detection threshold. Hence, these two effects (higher background, and lens subtraction) reduce our detection threshold compared to the MUSE-Wide survey by almost 0.5 dex. The centre of the datacube is less sensitive to faint emitters, which cannot be avoided, but at shorter wavelengths we are also offset by 0.4 dex from channels less affected by the lunar continuum. For future surveys, as a trade-off for the number of observations, a tighter constraint on the moon illumination may be considered to reduce the sky background.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to altering the observing conditions, we can consider an alternative selection method, which may improve the likelihood of a lens discovery. Our current selection criteria (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>) uses a single-fibre velocity dispersion as a proxy for stellar mass, and hence <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>. Instead we could directly measure <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> from a mass-follows-light profile, (such as those used in our upper-limit lensing calculations), and select galaxies to maximize the lensing cross-section. However, using the light profile measured <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> as a part of the selection process introduces additional computation, which will require additional cuts in parameter space to be efficient. Instead the current technique is considerably simpler, and the <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> scales with the velocity dispersion (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An alternative to the \u2018targeted\u2019 blind search methods like MNELLS is to exploit large IFU surveys. For example the MaNGA survey (Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) has a sample median redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, z\\, \\rangle$|</span>\u00a0=\u00a00.05 (100\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> &lt;\u03c3\u2009&lt; 400\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>), which is comparable to MNELLS. The full MaNGA survey will take IFU observations of over 10\u2009000 ETGs and hence will discover a number of low-<em>z</em> strong gravitational lenses. To date, Talbot et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) worked with a sample of 2812 ETGs, and so far has produced 2\u20136 candidate lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although MaNGA\u2019s median redshift is comparable to that of MNELLS, it aims to observe a broad range of galaxy sizes, including a high fraction of low-\u03c3 ETGs. The larger (higher-\u03c3) ETGs typically lie more distant than their median redshift, so that the same fraction of <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> is imaged within the FoV (See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). This has two implications: First, the low-<em>z</em>, low-\u03c3 galaxies are less likely to be gravitational strong lenses so the number of discovered lenses is likely reduced. Secondly, the higher \u03c3 galaxies which are more likely to be lenses lie and higher redshift and are hence subject to larger DM uncertainties. Such lenses, (e.g. J1701+3722, Smith <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.12), are complimentary to SNELLS/MNELLS nearby lenses, but not identical. However, lenses within this redshift range may offer an avenue to address the differences between the SLACS and SNELLS/MNELLS conflicting samples.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443705 id=\"201443705\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the first results from the ongoing MNELLS survey, and a complementary archival sample, searching for nearby strong-lensing ETGs. We have observed 16 new targets (14 to full depth) and selected 36 comparable galaxies that were publicly available from the ESO archive at the end of February 2019. We search within each datacube for background sources that are multiply imaged or single-imaged but closely projected to the \u2018lens\u2019. We process each pipeline-reduced datacube to filter out the foreground galaxy and then search the residuals for emission lines with an automated detection process. We then manually verify the detections and find that human interpretation is key to reliable identification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From the total sample, we have discovered one new galaxy-scale strong lens, J0403\u22120239, which is consistent with an MW-like IMF, \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a01.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.17 (see Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), for an assumed old stellar population. The newly acquired high S/N FORS2 spectrum of J0403\u22120239 will be used to precisely constrain the age of the stellar population and hence \u03b1. A further two new low-<em>z</em> cluster-scale lenses were discovered in which the lensing mass is dominated by DM for any plausible IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have discovered nine galaxies with closely projected but single-imaged sources (<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a06\u2009arcsec), which we use to augment the constraints on the IMF via our \u2018upper-limit lensing\u2019 technique (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Of these systems, J0202\u22125055 shows a hint of having a counter-image to its innermost source, and hence could become the fifth low-<em>z</em> lens with additional observations. If the inner image has no counter-image, the configuration implies a system that is likely consistent with an MW-like or lighter IMF. Of the other eight, only J0202\u20130107 favours a Salpeter or lighter IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combining the four confirmed low-<em>z</em> lenses with nine closely projected but single-imaged systems from this paper and two taken from Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; SNL-4 and J0728+4005), we infer the mean and intrinsic scatter of the ETG population, assuming a lognormal distribution for \u03b1. The population has \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 and a 90\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence standard deviation of \u03b1 of 0.24. This is less than the \u2329\u03b1\u232a\u00a0=\u00a01.09\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08 and \u03c3\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.32 from only the confirmed lenses (Collier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). This implies that there is a higher likelihood of discovering strong lensing around massive galaxies that have higher stellar mass (i.e. more compact) due to their increased surface mass density. Therefore, although SNELLS and MNELLS lenses on average measure an \u03b1 a few\u00a0per\u2009cent larger than MW-like, the total population lies close to an MW-like IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We tested our detection flux thresholds within the MNELLS datacubes and predict that we reach a flux limit of 10<sup>\u221216.5</sup> erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. Our central sensitivity is 0.35 dex lower due to the foreground galaxy continuum. From the MUSE-wide results, we predict that one in 25 targets will be multiply imaged strong lens. So far with 14 targets we have two closely projected but single-imaged sources and no strong lenses (our reported strong-lensing galaxies are from the archival sample), which is consistent within the Poisson statistics of these predictions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper has presented the first of a series of MNELLS observations, with 21 more galaxies observed in P103 and P104 as of February 2020. Additionally, the faint object camera and spectragraph (FOCAS) on Subaru (Ozaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) offers an alternative to MUSE, and we are extending our survey technique to the Northern hemisphere. From this data set, J0202\u22125055 is a promising candidate for future follow-up observations as it appears a highly likely to be a multiply imaged strong lens for any typical IMF and has the potential for multiple source planes. With this large array of incoming data, the likelihood of discovering new low-<em>z</em> strong-lensing galaxies in the forthcoming years is high.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443712 id=\"201443712\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WC was supported by an STFC studentship (ST/N50404X/1). RJS and JRL are supported by the STFC Durham Astronomy Consolidated Grant (ST/P000541/1). This research has made use of the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED), which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This work is based on observations collected at the European Organisation for Astronomical Research in the Southern Hemisphere under various ESO programme IDs, retrieved through the ESO Science Archive Facility. This publication makes use of data products from the Two Micron All Sky Survey, which is a joint project of the University of Massachusetts and the Infrared Processing and Analysis Center/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Science Foundation. This work made use of data from observations obtained as part of the VISTA Hemisphere Survey, ESO programme, 179.A-2010 (PI: McMahon)</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443714 id=\"201443714\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">In principle the archive could be searched for strong gravitational lenses independent of specific morphologies or redshift. However, this is beyond the scope of this work, specific to the IMF of massive ETGs.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">BCGs are excluded from the targeted survey as the lensing mass is typically dominated by DM, and the galaxy has a low surface brightness and hence mass density. This leads to an <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> significantly larger than found in a typical isolated galaxy. Hence, the DM modelling dominates the uncertainty on the constraints of the IMF.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201443717 id=\"201443717\" class=\"backreferences-title\" data-legacy-id=ref1>REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bacon</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div></span> et al.\u00a0.</span>, <div class=\"year\">2014</div>, <div class=\"source \">The Messenger</div>, <div class=\"volume\">157</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">13</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\">\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib2\" data-legacy-id=\"bib2\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib2\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib2\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib2\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bessell</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M. G.</div></span> et al.\u00a0.</span>, <div class=\"year\">2000</div>, <div class=\"source \">AJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">120</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1579</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1086/301513\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1086/301513</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/301513\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1086%2F301513\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1086%2F301513\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib61\" data-legacy-id=\"bib61\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib61\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib61\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib61\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zwicky</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">F.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">1937</div>, <div class=\"source \">Phys. Rev.</div>, <div class=\"volume\">51</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">290</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRev.51.290\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1103/PhysRev.51.290</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRev.51.290\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1103%2FPhysRev.51.290\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1103%2FPhysRev.51.290\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443719 id=\"201443719\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: EXAMPLE REJECTED EMITTER DETECTION</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this appendix we show an example of a rejected detection (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>). Here it is clear that the detection has found a residual in the H\u2009\u03b1 at the redshift of the candidate galaxy. It can be automated to reject such emission during the detection process, using the known lens redshift. It is also clear that the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission line is not within the wavelength range of the MUSE instrument, and hence the panel which would contain a narrow-band extraction is left blank.</p>                        <a id=\"201443721\" scrollto-destination=\"201443721\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=Kpv0ONmAHI1Rpk4TIXjqENybG5cF0pGlZzqsWeM4IFCbNjrjzN~Y9yy5DDqjFhyie~P2BZg-5CtSkw3j7IQO-VYJCWjd2~ze3wS8Ff2z4oBTVPNsm0CaKAn~pasQLp4eCKctur1-6GzRD4pA4ZLPxUwr9qRCt2vNFiyWueKr1RtooPGPRxq6PTdRI~0jw-84jMqIc8yeJTtzgR0X26ocRLwTri8gpS27IafG7nQy9KP2bUU1J~LCWu4mqYwcWU-P-hR7drcd8klL~~jTpFm1TEy-i~T4bPYKWSEFx8~qkGtCkHOXo9V~7f64eUN1d8JQlVVfVkB4rw~mCxmjT5dO5A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An example rejected detection from an MNELLS observation of J0058\u22121628. The four panels across the top show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around the [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009iii] and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. Here there is no [O\u2009ii], as it out of the MUSE wavelength range for the fitted redshift. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, which shows that this is likely a residual of the lens subtraction. The best-fitting redshift is 0.03735.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443721/staa602figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443721\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=VPS9CdB~kOunbgK4S9MpLq3gYss9KPxrdpoYps4w6RkY6JeMlthzjX56zY06uX3k5cnUQfI6IV1iHTEoN0HI2CRnJLZfmEtm-8zPGMaoRIMv7R2gfGLlVBWD7-BzM5cut1gCYkgo3eLwCFYkykieh58GqNJv1d1NZLJLzuU5~DiB967RniBWH60nHvC~LmpkZmMIw5p1qtrdFCVeA1EXdwg2jakgyJr9Sty0182eYoS4ooLtzis1-dil56UDAEbR67RqtHxXvBIrW-iPM87NAIuYEsTU4lcyRrkFqyqymV~q06G7pqFTIY9OyejXUz9vZDpVU8QhG8kFwimaX7-E2A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443721&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example rejected detection from an MNELLS observation of J0058\u22121628. The four panels across the top show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. Here there is no [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], as it out of the MUSE wavelength range for the fitted redshift. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, which shows that this is likely a residual of the lens subtraction. The best-fitting redshift is 0.03735.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=Kpv0ONmAHI1Rpk4TIXjqENybG5cF0pGlZzqsWeM4IFCbNjrjzN~Y9yy5DDqjFhyie~P2BZg-5CtSkw3j7IQO-VYJCWjd2~ze3wS8Ff2z4oBTVPNsm0CaKAn~pasQLp4eCKctur1-6GzRD4pA4ZLPxUwr9qRCt2vNFiyWueKr1RtooPGPRxq6PTdRI~0jw-84jMqIc8yeJTtzgR0X26ocRLwTri8gpS27IafG7nQy9KP2bUU1J~LCWu4mqYwcWU-P-hR7drcd8klL~~jTpFm1TEy-i~T4bPYKWSEFx8~qkGtCkHOXo9V~7f64eUN1d8JQlVVfVkB4rw~mCxmjT5dO5A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An example rejected detection from an MNELLS observation of J0058\u22121628. The four panels across the top show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around the [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009iii] and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. Here there is no [O\u2009ii], as it out of the MUSE wavelength range for the fitted redshift. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, which shows that this is likely a residual of the lens subtraction. The best-fitting redshift is 0.03735.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443721/staa602figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443721\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=VPS9CdB~kOunbgK4S9MpLq3gYss9KPxrdpoYps4w6RkY6JeMlthzjX56zY06uX3k5cnUQfI6IV1iHTEoN0HI2CRnJLZfmEtm-8zPGMaoRIMv7R2gfGLlVBWD7-BzM5cut1gCYkgo3eLwCFYkykieh58GqNJv1d1NZLJLzuU5~DiB967RniBWH60nHvC~LmpkZmMIw5p1qtrdFCVeA1EXdwg2jakgyJr9Sty0182eYoS4ooLtzis1-dil56UDAEbR67RqtHxXvBIrW-iPM87NAIuYEsTU4lcyRrkFqyqymV~q06G7pqFTIY9OyejXUz9vZDpVU8QhG8kFwimaX7-E2A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443721&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example rejected detection from an MNELLS observation of J0058\u22121628. The four panels across the top show the spatial extent of the emission in narrow-band slices around the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and H\u2009\u03b1, which tend to be the strongest optical emission lines. Here there is no [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], as it out of the MUSE wavelength range for the fitted redshift. Below is the spectrum extracted within a 2\u2009arcsec diameter aperture, which shows that this is likely a residual of the lens subtraction. The best-fitting redshift is 0.03735.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201443722 id=\"201443722\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX B: MULTIPLE CLOSE EMITTERS \u2013 MORE INFORMATION</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443723 id=\"201443723\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9-1>B1 2MASXJ00585131\u22121628092</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The first system we will discuss in this section is 2MASXJ00585131\u22121628092 (J0058\u22121628). This is a redshift 0.054 massive elliptical with a companion separated by 11.5\u2009arcsec. This system was previously observed with SINFONI; however, due to the small FoV of the instrument, three background clustered [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emitters were outside of the instrument FoV. However in MUSE, these emitters are detected and are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb1\" data-open=\"figb1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201443725\" scrollto-destination=\"201443725\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=xqX6lfx2Ui7nm-U7XuIiSw2vKGXG3EI7evOkGSr2VZKhQbT4dBjwVeld3GVyaKxUJE3Xs1tlghN8C5rhVD99P0OL5zr3udMhjLRjBA9D0xQOAUgH-MB-BKswu-BBdjxiGpv1YHzTD-390qdm5XyRwxAsljbTV1XnUbiBTgkIGg-SSRZX48WVWNUgKc-OZ5wdwxgkut9JXZlZGA5I3ZDjHbHsqLAtClSAcIzw6J8j4sdeZsMumNysV5D1ehgDKo0IoQ5Jef9a7Q-lR1tMn9EcavZHAddqCEWJqZEN~eMmK~MJsH~vHmioLQTmPzrDLHs6Uoe63qjqZ3OeD-3BorHqig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628, and the extracted background emitters. (a) The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628 collapsed over the full wavelength range, overlaid with contours of the background [O\u2009iii] emission at common redshift, labelled A, B and C. Panels b,c,d) displays the [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009iii] emission for each of the three emitters. The line strength ratios vary between the images, with very weak [O\u2009ii] emission only present in image A. Image C can be seen to have a velocity offset compared to A and B, in all three panels. Therefore we do not consider these to have originated from a single source.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443725/staa602figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443725\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=oQcHhUT8m~nfHYGiPcfvVsNGXtzGbrz7fDGhCKVKJbc2eA~8SFyn1S5rNVt3cifOwoHbCupiu9oc5c~9zsOBkAd6twql~SCEWCNaNbjWLLMnDQFmKMBMsnfaKDzDC8Wnsgbi6gJ5HFeHG7i9w1cC0rxJeklNFj4Q4sTHeOTH9aWwnzTv7gCv52X91DPq0UiIIdwU8VrfOUlIe8UFh7z3Jqtx5dqrffQvFb6BVx-OubX6gXVtaXE0SV7RsCwR73WX70fNq2kFxpM91sRhd3hIDylL8LJ7j~wRda7s6a~rNp43awiapi2rXrg7y3MGoKE1t5XClJ~0IP1yxyjEv1BVBg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443725&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628, and the extracted background emitters. (a) The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628 collapsed over the full wavelength range, overlaid with contours of the background [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission at common redshift, labelled A, B and C. Panels b,c,d) displays the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission for each of the three emitters. The line strength ratios vary between the images, with very weak [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission only present in image A. Image C can be seen to have a velocity offset compared to A and B, in all three panels. Therefore we do not consider these to have originated from a single source.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=xqX6lfx2Ui7nm-U7XuIiSw2vKGXG3EI7evOkGSr2VZKhQbT4dBjwVeld3GVyaKxUJE3Xs1tlghN8C5rhVD99P0OL5zr3udMhjLRjBA9D0xQOAUgH-MB-BKswu-BBdjxiGpv1YHzTD-390qdm5XyRwxAsljbTV1XnUbiBTgkIGg-SSRZX48WVWNUgKc-OZ5wdwxgkut9JXZlZGA5I3ZDjHbHsqLAtClSAcIzw6J8j4sdeZsMumNysV5D1ehgDKo0IoQ5Jef9a7Q-lR1tMn9EcavZHAddqCEWJqZEN~eMmK~MJsH~vHmioLQTmPzrDLHs6Uoe63qjqZ3OeD-3BorHqig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628, and the extracted background emitters. (a) The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628 collapsed over the full wavelength range, overlaid with contours of the background [O\u2009iii] emission at common redshift, labelled A, B and C. Panels b,c,d) displays the [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009iii] emission for each of the three emitters. The line strength ratios vary between the images, with very weak [O\u2009ii] emission only present in image A. Image C can be seen to have a velocity offset compared to A and B, in all three panels. Therefore we do not consider these to have originated from a single source.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443725/staa602figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443725\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=oQcHhUT8m~nfHYGiPcfvVsNGXtzGbrz7fDGhCKVKJbc2eA~8SFyn1S5rNVt3cifOwoHbCupiu9oc5c~9zsOBkAd6twql~SCEWCNaNbjWLLMnDQFmKMBMsnfaKDzDC8Wnsgbi6gJ5HFeHG7i9w1cC0rxJeklNFj4Q4sTHeOTH9aWwnzTv7gCv52X91DPq0UiIIdwU8VrfOUlIe8UFh7z3Jqtx5dqrffQvFb6BVx-OubX6gXVtaXE0SV7RsCwR73WX70fNq2kFxpM91sRhd3hIDylL8LJ7j~wRda7s6a~rNp43awiapi2rXrg7y3MGoKE1t5XClJ~0IP1yxyjEv1BVBg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443725&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628, and the extracted background emitters. (a) The MUSE data of J0058\u22121628 collapsed over the full wavelength range, overlaid with contours of the background [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission at common redshift, labelled A, B and C. Panels b,c,d) displays the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission for each of the three emitters. The line strength ratios vary between the images, with very weak [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission only present in image A. Image C can be seen to have a velocity offset compared to A and B, in all three panels. Therefore we do not consider these to have originated from a single source.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The three emitters share very strong [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission, but do not share the same [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], and H\u2009\u03b2. There is also a significant velocity offset \u223c200\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> between C, and the other two, but only 10\u2019s\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> between A and B, seen clearly in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb1\" data-open=\"figb1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1(e)</a>. On face value, considering the images A and B, the system appears similar to J2357\u22123445, which we label a lens. In this case, the candidate images are separated by \u223c28.28\u2009arcsec, and &gt;\u200915\u2009arcsec from the galaxy centre, which far exceeds the stellar galaxy-galaxy lensing regime. However, this lens does not appear to be part of a larger galaxy group, and hence is unlikely to have the large dark matter halo required to have such large image separation (unlike J2357\u22123445). Finally, there is a weak H\u03b3 line, seen in candidate image A, which is not seen in the spectrum of candidate B.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Therefore we label this system as a clustered group of background sources, and not a lensing system. Deeper observations and a more detailed understanding of the local matter distribution would be required to clearly define this system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=201443728 id=\"201443728\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9-2>B2 2MASXJ13522523\u22123456007</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The second system is 2MASXJ1352252\u22123456007 (J1352\u22123456), an E/S0 galaxy at redshift 0.03817 (Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), with no nearby galaxies of comparable size. Our MNELLS observations detect a group of three emitters separated from the galaxy centre by between 5 and 7\u2009arcsec. These are detected at redshift \u223c0.549, via strong [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and weaker [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. A fourth emitter can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb2\" data-open=\"figb2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B2a</a>) to the south, but is poorly configured with the other three sources, and has a velocity offset of 210\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> so is not considered part of the candidate lens system.</p>                        <a id=\"201443730\" scrollto-destination=\"201443730\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figb2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602figb2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=oGf4WU8T6pm5dKGh4qLIvVXeZ7vWCkserraX8H64fLfsAq-OdbmmNBVfhl15lW7CgzchBHml9tK1gvgTtW~QBq2RwuFNDygmPWY9-jeQPqb1AVbzI~QyYCPGwNjom72DcVORAa~MvmBhfhEy71UCmfBmRrMC6VqAgqOVqtfzlQ3JIZqkPBzR-T339iyR-H6iTRK-2JvHWfGT6r17U1lkVHRKaAcrcNREMSowG40MA~3fQ3U9mluN-ZcMZYIT-yZez4H8Qy5pPtW~x4yP~OlbRykcSedFdU7~U3P14qqXsfW6qwtTzb-lB6nom2I9-gRlNGkDywXkIJKyfJyyB282sw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data of J1352\u22123456, with the extracted background emitters spectra. Panel a) The MUSE imaging of J1352\u22123456 collapsed over the full wavelength range. Overlaid are the contours of the [O\u2009iii] emission for the rejected candidate lensed images. Panels b,c,d) show the [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009iii] respectively for each of the labelled emitters. The line strength ratios vary, between images A and C, along with all three being offset in velocity space from each other (seen most clearly in panel c), H\u2009\u03b2).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443730/staa602figb2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443730\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602figb2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=0hRFe-9MZexBIrfss1LdtTxpqSqDfllhKZ597JkQHPxxT194~uAolV6miIHpZgxZk-IWp01kzGasAnlQAgJ3LmzWocDya6dJhsIFDZiirMPhbFx4K2yPPlpbDs6~I1RaFZQeyqqGYiZ-YVnZaThO2ShXLTDuFN8PZJYohK8Y6lYBtnXgU4OW5-accSQofFOXkU9VnEox8ECHRoT5Vp12ppYOe2t3EK-L6zqol4mYwmcO1QecP2L60qw4rfh525kw0vqo6y3ZdmoAOhtef8di4dUN1CDrLk-BVsPuIEcfbgGtWgNfGuiJ7R5FssL-8vn7fdPbcDJ~yE2V5rZomtZRWw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443730&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data of J1352\u22123456, with the extracted background emitters spectra. Panel a) The MUSE imaging of J1352\u22123456 collapsed over the full wavelength range. Overlaid are the contours of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission for the rejected candidate lensed images. Panels b,c,d) show the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] respectively for each of the labelled emitters. The line strength ratios vary, between images A and C, along with all three being offset in velocity space from each other (seen most clearly in panel c), H\u2009\u03b2).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figb2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/m_staa602figb2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&amp;Signature=oGf4WU8T6pm5dKGh4qLIvVXeZ7vWCkserraX8H64fLfsAq-OdbmmNBVfhl15lW7CgzchBHml9tK1gvgTtW~QBq2RwuFNDygmPWY9-jeQPqb1AVbzI~QyYCPGwNjom72DcVORAa~MvmBhfhEy71UCmfBmRrMC6VqAgqOVqtfzlQ3JIZqkPBzR-T339iyR-H6iTRK-2JvHWfGT6r17U1lkVHRKaAcrcNREMSowG40MA~3fQ3U9mluN-ZcMZYIT-yZez4H8Qy5pPtW~x4yP~OlbRykcSedFdU7~U3P14qqXsfW6qwtTzb-lB6nom2I9-gRlNGkDywXkIJKyfJyyB282sw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The MUSE data of J1352\u22123456, with the extracted background emitters spectra. Panel a) The MUSE imaging of J1352\u22123456 collapsed over the full wavelength range. Overlaid are the contours of the [O\u2009iii] emission for the rejected candidate lensed images. Panels b,c,d) show the [O\u2009ii], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009iii] respectively for each of the labelled emitters. The line strength ratios vary, between images A and C, along with all three being offset in velocity space from each other (seen most clearly in panel c), H\u2009\u03b2).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201443730/staa602figb2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201443730\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa602/1/staa602figb2.jpeg?Expires=1611464611&Signature=0hRFe-9MZexBIrfss1LdtTxpqSqDfllhKZ597JkQHPxxT194~uAolV6miIHpZgxZk-IWp01kzGasAnlQAgJ3LmzWocDya6dJhsIFDZiirMPhbFx4K2yPPlpbDs6~I1RaFZQeyqqGYiZ-YVnZaThO2ShXLTDuFN8PZJYohK8Y6lYBtnXgU4OW5-accSQofFOXkU9VnEox8ECHRoT5Vp12ppYOe2t3EK-L6zqol4mYwmcO1QecP2L60qw4rfh525kw0vqo6y3ZdmoAOhtef8di4dUN1CDrLk-BVsPuIEcfbgGtWgNfGuiJ7R5FssL-8vn7fdPbcDJ~yE2V5rZomtZRWw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201443730&ar=5775322&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa602figb2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE data of J1352\u22123456, with the extracted background emitters spectra. Panel a) The MUSE imaging of J1352\u22123456 collapsed over the full wavelength range. Overlaid are the contours of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission for the rejected candidate lensed images. Panels b,c,d) show the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], H\u2009\u03b2 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] respectively for each of the labelled emitters. The line strength ratios vary, between images A and C, along with all three being offset in velocity space from each other (seen most clearly in panel c), H\u2009\u03b2).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectra of the three objects are very similar, with A and C of comparable line strengths, and B the faintest. The largest velocity offset is between A and C is \u223c90\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, with B and C offset by &lt;50\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. However, in this system the problematic feature is the distance from the lens to the images, and the separation between the images. Where these images close, and hint at a some linked structure this may bear a resemblance to the lens reported in Smith, Lucey\u00a0&amp; Edge (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), with a large arc, and no clearly observable counter-image. However, no evidence is present to define this as an arc. The separation from the lens of \u223c6.5\u2009arcsec lies at the limit of twice the expected <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>, for a similarly massive galaxy and hence unlikely to lie within the strongly lensing regime. Secondly to form three distinct images, each separated by over 1\u2009arcsec is an unlikely lensing configuration. In addition there is no evidence for these candidate images forming a single arc, as no emission is detected in the spaces between C, B and A.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to understand this lensing system much deeper data would be required to test for the presence of a faint inner image, very close to the candidate lens core, or to identify C, B and A as a single arc. Furthermore these potential images lie at a distance which would only add weak constraints to the required mass for there to be no detectable counter image. Hence, we label these emitters a group of background galaxies.</p>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n emitter. Then the number of detectable counter-images to the observed image is extracted. Following the framework outlined in Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), we estimate the probability that the system only has a single detected image, for each trial value of <em>M</em>/<em>L</em>. The quoted masses are <em>total</em> lensing masses, including dark matter. The luminosity is <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-band 2MASS for J2357\u22123445, and WFPC2 F814W and 2MASS <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> for J1516+0701. The uncertainty is 0.1\u2009arcsec for <em>R</em><sub>ap</sub>. This follows through into the aperture mass as a 10\u00a0per\u2009cent uncertainty, and into the aperture luminosity as 2\u00a0per\u2009cent. We estimate that the uncertainty in the dark matter fraction is \u223c5\u00a0per\u2009cent.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" The quoted masses are <em>total</em> lensing masses, including dark matter. The luminosity is <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-band 2MASS for J2357\u22123445, and WFPC2 F814W and 2MASS <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> for J1516+0701. The uncertainty is 0.1\u2009arcsec for <em>R</em><sub>ap</sub>. This follows through into the aperture mass as a 10\u00a0per\u2009cent uncertainty, and into the aperture luminosity as 2\u00a0per\u2009cent. We estimate that the uncertainty in the dark matter fraction is \u223c5\u00a0per\u2009cent.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" We define each galaxy by its 2MASS ID and in the second column the target object from the MUSE data header. For each galaxy we report the number of emitters, the exposure time, and if there is evidence for a multiple- or single-imaged lens system. The distance to the nearest emission-line source within 10\u2009arcsec is noted, or the distances to the multiple images. We also note two \u2018potential\u2019 systems that have single emission-line detections which we do not find compelling.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>2MASX<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Target (header)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$t_{\\rm \\exp }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Total Emitters<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Multiply imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Single imaged<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Ang. the MUSE archive. We define each galaxy by its 2MASS ID and in the second column the target object from the MUSE data header. For each galaxy we report the number of emitters, the exposure time, and if there is evidence for a multiple- or single-imaged lens system. The distance to the nearest emission-line source within 10\u2009arcsec is noted, or the distances to the multiple images. class=\"widget widget-AdBlock widget-instance-RiserAd\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "Action": "Not saving duplicates", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": ">For full access to this pdf, sign in to an existing account, or purchase an annual subscription."}, "Status": "Skipped", "Link": "https://academic.oup.com/view-large/201443570", "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Action": "Processed via pandas", "Status": "Complete"}}}}, "Paper Overview": {"authors": ["Collier, William P.", "Smith, Russell J.", "Lucey, John R."], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "issn": "0035-8711", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/staa602", "start_page": "271", "number": "1", "publication_year": "2020/03/1", "end_page": "292", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:2002.07191", "author_address": ["AA(Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, Departments of Physics, University of Durham, Durham DH1 3LE, UK), AB(Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, Departments of Physics, University of Durham, Durham DH1 3LE, UK), AC(Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy, Departments of Physics, University of Durham, Durham DH1 3LE, UK)"], "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: elliptical and lenticular", "cD", "galaxies: stellar content", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2020MNRAS.494..271C", "volume": "494", "Title": "MNELLS: the MUSE nearby early-type galaxy lens locator survey", "abstract": "Low-redshift strong-lensing galaxies can provide robust measurements of the stellar mass-to-light ratios in early-type galaxies (ETGs), and hence constrain variations in the stellar initial mass function (IMF). At present, only a few such systems are known. Here, we report the first results from a blind search for gravitationally lensed emission-line sources behind 52 massive z &lt; 0.07 ETGs with Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) integral field spectroscopy. For 16 galaxies, new observations were acquired, whilst the other 36 were analysed from archival data. This project has previously yielded one confirmed galaxy-scale strong lens (J0403-0239) that we report in an earlier paper. J0403-0239 has since received follow-up observations, presented here, which indicate support for our earlier IMF results. Three cluster-scale, and hence dark-matter-dominated, lensing systems were also discovered (central galaxies of A4059, A2052, and AS555). For nine further galaxies, we detect a singly imaged but closely projected source within 6 arcsec (including one candidate with sources at three different redshifts); such cases can be exploited to derive upper limits on the IMF mass-excess factor, \u03b1. Combining the new lens and new upper limits, with the previously discovered systems, we infer an average &lt;\u03b1&gt; = 1.06 \u00b1 0.08 (marginalized over the intrinsic scatter), which is inconsistent with a Salpeter-like IMF (\u03b1 = 1.55) at the 6\u03c3 level. We test the detection threshold in these short-exposure MUSE observations with the injection and recovery of simulated sources, and predict that one in 25 observations is expected to yield a new strong-lens system. Our observational results are consistent with this expected yield."}}
